{% endif %}
{% endif %} {% if 41-validity-scales == true %}
Validity Scales
Scale
Score
Description
{% if 169-positive-impression-score != undefined %}
Positive Impression
{{ 169-positive-impression-score }}
Items rated extremely positively, and are in most cases unrealistic. Often indicates an overly positive description of youth’s behavior, but can also be the result of:
  • Youth’s exemplary behavior in a particular setting
  • Youth being extremely well-behaved for a specific parent or teacher
  • Rater has a tendency to forget positive traits and remember negative ones
  • Rater is motivated to describe the youth as “problem-free,” for example, wanting to avoid stigmatizing labels or services
  • Rater completed the Conners 3 erroneously, such as comparing the youth to another who has more difficulty (e.g., a quiet student in a class of troublemakers or a youth whose sibling shows severe clinical symptoms) rather than thinking of the youth’s behavior independently of any other youth’s behavior
{% endif %} {% if 170-negative-impression-score != undefined %}
Negative Impression
{{ 170-negative-impression-score }}
A set of items that describe extremely negative behaviors that are unlikely to be true all the time. Often indicates an overly negative description of the youth’s behavior, but can also be the result of:
  • The youth really does misbehave most of the time, as seen in some severe clinical cases
  • There may be some variables that negatively impact the youth’s functioning in a particular setting (e.g., a student with a math disorder may show worse behavior in math class than in art class)
  • The rater may have very high standards that are difficult for the youth to meet
  • The rater may be highly motivated to describe the youth as problematic in order to obtain services or shift the youth to another placement
  • The rater may be erroneously comparing the youth to others who are older or who are exceptionally well-behaved.
{% endif %} {% if 171-inconsistency-index-score != undefined %}
Inconsistency Index
{{ 171-inconsistency-index-score }}
Based on responses to pairs of items that tend to be rated similarly. When there is inconsistency in responses to similar items, this suggests that scores may not accurately reflect the individual due to a careless or unusual response to some items. Random responding, variable attention, or comprehension difficulties can contribute to this.
{% endif %}
{% endif %}
{% endif %} {% if D-KEFS == true %}

Attention & Executive Function

D-KEFS

D-KEFS is a comprehensive assessment of higher-level cognitive functions—such as attention, language, and perception—in both children and adults (ages 8:0-89:0 years). The D-KEFS consists of nine tests that measure a wide spectrum of verbal and nonverbal executive functions. Each test is designed to be a standalone instrument that can be administered individually or along with other D-KEFS tests. The selection of tests to be administered depends on the assessment needs of the specific examinee or the time constraints on the examiner.

Subtest
Score
Description
{% if 206-trail-making-test-score != undefined %}
Trail Making Test
{{ 206-trail-making-test-score }}
This test consists of five conditions. The primary executive-function task is the Number-Letter Switching condition, a visual-motor sequencing procedure, which is a measure of flexibility of thinking. The other four conditions allow the examiner to evaluate several key component processes needed to perform the switching task. These fundamental components include visual scanning, number sequencing, letter sequencing, and motor speed in drawing lines.
{% endif %} {% if 207-verbal-fluency-test-score != undefined %}
Verbal Fluency Test
{{ 207-verbal-fluency-test-score }}
This test is composed of three conditions:
  • Letter Fluency: the examinee is asked to say words that begin with a specified letter as quickly as possible in three trials of 60 seconds each
    • Taps the individual’s ability to generate words fluently in an effortful, phonetic format
  • Category Fluency: the examinee is asked to say words that belong to a designated semantic category as quickly as possible in two trials of 60 seconds each
    • Taps the individual’s ability to generate words fluently from overlearned concepts
  • Category Switching: evaluates the examinee’s ability to alternate between saying words from two different semantic categories as quickly as possible for 60 seconds
    • Taps the individual’s ability to generate words fluently while simultaneously shifting between overlearned concepts
{% endif %} {% if 208-design-fluency-test-score != undefined %}
Design Fluency Test
{{ 208-design-fluency-test-score }}
This test is composed of three conditions. For each condition, the examinee is presented rows of boxes each containing an array of dots that the examinee must connect, with four lines only, to make a different design.
  • Condition 1: Filled dots
    • Each response box contains five filled dots, and the examinee is asked to draw as many designs as possible in 60 seconds, by connecting these dots.
    • Provides a basic test of design fluency.
  • Condition 2: Empty Dots Only
    • Each response box contains five filled dots and five unfilled (empty) dots. The examinee is required to inhibit connecting the filled dots and to connect only the unfilled dots in 60 seconds.
    • Measures both design fluency and response inhibition.
  • Condition 3: Switching
    • The examinee is again presented with response boxes that contain both filled and unfilled dots, and is asked to draw the designs by alternating connections between filled and unfilled dots.
    • Taps both design fluency and cognitive flexibility.
{% endif %} {% if 209-color-word-interference-test-score != undefined %}
Color-Word Interference Test
{{ 209-color-word-interference-test-score }}
This test measures the examinee’s ability to inhibit a more automatic verbal response (reading) in order to generate a conflicting response of naming a dissonant ink color. Another condition requires the examinee to switch back and forth between naming the dissonant ink colors and reading the conflicting words. This condition is a measure of both inhibition and cognitive flexibility.
{% endif %} {% if 210-sorting-test-score != undefined %}
Sorting Test
{{ 210-sorting-test-score }}
This tests consists of two conditions:
  • Free Sorting: the examinee is presented six mixed-up cards that display both perceptual features and printed words. The examinee is asked to sort the cards into two groups, with three cards per group, according to as many different concepts or rules as possible, and to describe the concepts employed to generate each sort. Each of the two card sets has a maximum of eight target sorts: three sorts based on verbal-semantic information from the printed words and five based on visual-spatial features or patterns on the cards. This provides a window into their ability to initiate problem-solving behavior.
  • Sort Recognition: the examiner sorts the same sets of cards into two groups, with three cards per group, according to eight target sorts. After each sort is made by the examiner, the examinee attempts to identify and describe the correct rules or concepts used to generate the sort. This provides a window into their conceptual-reasoning skills.
{% endif %} {% if 211-twenty-questions-test-score != undefined %}
Twenty Questions Test
{{ 211-twenty-questions-test-score }}
On this test, the examinee is presented with a stimulus page depicting pictures of 30 common objects. The examinee tried to ask the fewest number of yes/no questions in order to identify the unknown target object. Executive functions tapped by this test include the individual’s ability to identify the various categories and subcategories represented in the 30 objects and to formulate abstract, yes/no questions that eliminate the maximum number of objects regardless of the examiner’s answer.
{% endif %} {% if 212-word-context-test-score != undefined %}
Word Context Test
{{ 212-word-context-test-score }}
The examinee’s main task in this test is to discover the meaning of made-up or mystery words based on clues given in sentences. For each mystery word, the examinee is shown five sentences (clues) that help him or her to decode the meaning of the word. With each new clue-sentence for the word, previously presented sentences are also displayed. The first sentence for each word provides only vague or general clues about the mystery word’s meaning. Each subsequent clue sentence provides progressively more detailed information. The examinee tries to decode the mystery word with as few clue sentences as possible and is asked to continue reporting the correct response to the remaining clue sentences of each item. This test is a means of evaluating executive functions in the verbal modality and assessing skills such as deductive reasoning, integration of multiple bits of information, hypothesis testing, and flexibility of thinking.
{% endif %} {% if 213-tower-test-score != undefined %}
Tower Test
{{ 213-tower-test-score }}
The materials for this test include five disks that vary is size from small to large and a board with three vertical pegs. Each item begins by the examiner’s placing from two to five disks on the pegs in a predetermined starting position and displaying a picture of the tower to be built (i.e., the ending position). The examinee’s task is to move the disks across the three pegs to build the target tower in the fewest number of moves possible. In constructing the target towers, the examinee must follow two rules: (a) to move only one disk at a time and (b) never to place a larger disk over a smaller disk. Process measures include first-move completion time, total number of moves, item-completion time, final achievement (correct or incorrect tower), and number of rule violations. This test measures spatial planning, rule learning, inhibition of impulsive responding, inhibition of perseverative responding, and establishing and maintaining the instructional set.
{% endif %} {% if 214-proverb-test-score != undefined %}
Proverb Test
{{ 214-proverb-test-score }}
In this test, proverbs are used as a means of assessing the nature of an individual’s verbal abstraction skills. The test consists of eight sayings that are presented in two conditions:
  • Free Inquiry and Multiple Choice.
  • For the Free Inquiry condition, the proverbs are read individually to examinees, who attempt to interpret them orally without assistance or cues.
  • For the Multiple Choice condition, the same eight proverbs are presented individually along with four alternative interpretations from which the examinee must select the best one.
  • The set of multiple-choice response alternatives for each proverb consists of (a) a correct abstract interpretation; (b) a correct concrete interpretation; (c) an incorrect, phonemically similar response, and (d) an unrelated saying. This task is designed for adolescents and adults aged 16-89.
{% endif %}
{% endif %} {% if RBANS == true %}

Attention & Executive Function

Repeatable Battery for the Assessment of Neuropsychological Status 

 RBANS

The Repeatable Battery for the Assessment of Neuropsychological Status measures attention, language, visuospatial/constructional abilities, and immediate and delayed memory.

Index
{% if 47-immediate-memory == true %}
Immediate Memory

Immediate Memory measures initial encoding and learning of complex and simple verbal information. Indicates the examinee’s ability to remember information immediately after it is presented.

Subtest
Score
Description
{% if 221-list-learning-score != undefined %}
List Learning
{{ 221-list-learning-score }}
Measures rote verbal memory functioning. A list of 10 semantically unrelated words is orally presented, and the examinee is asked to recall as many words as he or she can. This process is repeated over 4 learning trials.
{% endif %} {% if 222-story-memory-score != undefined %}
Story Memory
{{ 222-story-memory-score }}
Measures memory for conceptually related, meaningful verbal information. A short story is orally presented, and the examinee is asked to retell the story from memory. The same story is presented a second time, and the examinee is again asked to retell the story from memory.
{% endif %}
{% endif %} {% if 48-visuospatial-constructional == true %}
Visuospatial Constructional

Visuospatial Constructional measures basic visuospatial perception and the ability to copy a design from a model. Indicates examinee’s ability to perceive spatial relations and to construct a spatially accurate copy of a drawing.

Subtest
Score
Description
{% if 223-figure-copy-score != undefined %}
Figure Copy
{{ 223-figure-copy-score }}
Measures visuospatial reasoning, attention to visual details, motor programming, organization, and fine-motor ability. The examinee is shown a multipart geometric drawing and is asked to make an exact copy while the drawing remains on display.
{% endif %} {% if 224-line-orientation-score != undefined %}
Line Orientation
{{ 224-line-orientation-score }}
Measures the ability to correctly identify spatial orientation of lines in two-dimensions. The examinee is presented with a drawing that consists of 13 equal lines radiating out from a single point to form a semicircular fan-shaped pattern. All lines are numbered (1-13). Below this drawing are two lines that match two of the lines from the array above. The examinee is asked to identify which two lines they match. Ten trials are given, with different sets of test lines on each trial.
{% endif %}
{% endif %} {% if 49-language == true %}
Language

Language measures expressive language functioning. Indicates the examinee’s ability to respond verbally to either naming or retrieving learned material.

Subtest
Score
Description
{% if 225-picture-naming-score != undefined %}
Picture Naming
{{ 225-picture-naming-score }}
Measures confrontation naming skills. The examinee is presented with a series of pictured objects and is asked to name each one. A semantic cue is provided only if an object is obviously misperceived.
{% endif %} {% if 226-semantic-fluency-score != undefined %}
Semantic Fluency
{{ 226-semantic-fluency-score }}
Measures the examinee’s ability to retrieve and express words using a semantic prompt. The examinee is given one minute to name as many exemplars as possible from a given semantic category (fruits and vegetables on Form A, animals found in a zoo on Form B).
{% endif %}
{% endif %} {% if 50-attention == true %}
Attention

Attention measures simple auditory registration, visual scanning, and processing speed. Indicates the examinee’s capacity to remember and manipulate both visually and orally presented information in short-term memory storage.

Subtest
Score
Description
{% if 227-digit-span-score != undefined %}
Digit Span
{{ 227-digit-span-score }}
Measures auditory registration and brief focused attention. The examiner reads a string of digits and asks the examinee to repeat the digits in the same order. The length of the digit string increases by one on each trial.
{% endif %} {% if 228-coding-score != undefined %}
Coding
{{ 228-coding-score }}
Is a measure of brief, focused, visual attentions, visual scanning, and processing speed. The examinee is presented a page filled with rows of boxes with a number from 1-9 above each box (in random sequence), and a blank space below the number. At the top of the page is a key with a unique, simple, geometric shape beneath each of the numbers, 1 through 9. Using the key, the examinee is asked to fill in the number corresponding to each shape, for as many boxes as the examinee can complete in 90 seconds.
{% endif %}
{% endif %} {% if 51-delayed-memory == true %}
Delayed Memory

Delayed Memory measures of delayed recall and recognition for verbal and visual information. Indicates the examinee’s anterograde memory capacity.

Subtest
Score
Description
{% if 229-list-recall-score != undefined %}
List Recall
{{ 229-list-recall-score }}
Measures delayed recall for unrelated verbal information, and long-term verbal memory encoding and retrieval. The examinee is asked to recall the list of 10 words learned in the List Learning subtest.
{% endif %} {% if 230-list-recognition-score != undefined %}
List Recognition
{{ 230-list-recognition-score }}
Measures delayed recognition memory for unrelated verbal information, and long-term verbal memory encoding and retrieval. The examinee is read 20 words (10 targets, 10 distractors) and asked to indicate whether each word was on the word list.
{% endif %} {% if 231-story-recall-score != undefined %}
Story Recall
{{ 231-story-recall-score }}
Measured delayed recall for conceptually related verbal information, and long-term verbal memory encoding and retrieval for related information. The examinee is asked to retell the story they learned earlier.
{% endif %} {% if 232-figure-recall-score != undefined %}
Figure Recall
{{ 232-figure-recall-score }}
Measured delayed free recall for conceptually related visuospatial and detail information. The examinee is asked to draw the figure shown earlier from memory.
{% endif %}
{% endif %}
{% endif %} {% if NEPSY-II == true %}

Attention & Executive Function

A Developmental Neuropsychological Assessment - 2 

 NEPSY-II

NEPSY-II is a comprehensive instrument designed to assess neuropsychological development in preschool and school-age children. The NEPSY-II is designed to provide an assessment centered on specific diagnostic or referral questions and to allow for extended testing to provide more detailed or comprehensive information regarding the child’s neuropsychological functioning.

{% if 128-attention-and-executive-functioning == true %}
Attention and Executive Functioning

Attention and executive functions are multidimensional concepts that contain several related processes. Both concepts require self-regulatory skills and have some common subprocesses.

Subtest
Score
Description
{% if 557-animal-sorting-as-score != undefined %}
Animal Sorting (AS)
{{ 557-animal-sorting-as-score }}
This subtest is designed to assess the ability to formulate basic concepts, to transfer those concepts into action (sort into categories), and to shift set from one concept to another.
{% endif %} {% if 558-auditory-attention-aa-and-response-set-rs-score != undefined %}
Auditory Attention (AA) and Response Set (RS)
{{ 558-auditory-attention-aa-and-response-set-rs-score }}
Auditory Attention is designed to assess selective auditory attention and the ability to sustain it (vigilance).Response Set is designed to assess the ability to shift and maintain a new and complex set involving both inhibition of previously learned responses and correctly responding to matching or contrasting stimuli.
{% endif %} {% if 559-clocks-cl-score != undefined %}
Clocks (CL)
{{ 559-clocks-cl-score }}
This subtest is designed to assess planning and organization, visuoperceptual and visuospatial skills, and the concept of time in relation to analog clocks.
{% endif %} {% if 560-design-fluency-df-score != undefined %}
Design Fluency (DF)
{{ 560-design-fluency-df-score }}
This subtest is designed to assess the behavioral productivity in the child’s ability to generate unique designs.
{% endif %} {% if 561-inhibition-in-score != undefined %}
Inhibition (IN)
{{ 561-inhibition-in-score }}
This timed subtest is designed to assess the ability to inhibit automatic responses in favor of novel responses and the ability to switch between response types.
{% endif %} {% if 562-statue-st-score != undefined %}
Statue (ST)
{{ 562-statue-st-score }}
This subtest is designed to assess motor persistence and inhibition.
{% endif %}
{% endif %} {% if 129-language == true %}
Language

Language skills is the idea of input and output functions, that is, receptive and expressive skills. Receptive skills refer to the comprehension and decoding of speech. Expressive skills refer to language production.

Subtest
Score
Description
{% if 563-body-part-naming-bpn-and-identification-bpi-score != undefined %}
Body Part Naming (BPN) and Identification (BPI)
{{ 563-body-part-naming-bpn-and-identification-bpi-score }}
This subtest is designed to assess confrontation naming and name recognition, basic components of expressive and receptive language.
{% endif %} {% if 564-comprehension-of-instructions-ci-score != undefined %}
Comprehension of Instructions (CI)
{{ 564-comprehension-of-instructions-ci-score }}
This subtest is designed to assess the ability to receive, process, and execute oral instructions of increasing syntactic complexity.
{% endif %} {% if 565-oromotor-sequences-os-score != undefined %}
Oromotor Sequences (OS)
{{ 565-oromotor-sequences-os-score }}
This subtest is designed to assess Oromotor coordination.
{% endif %} {% if 566-phonological-processing-ph-score != undefined %}
Phonological Processing (PH)
{{ 566-phonological-processing-ph-score }}
This subtest is composed of two phonological processing tasks designed to assess phonemic awareness. Word Segment Recognition requires identification of words from word segments. Phonological Segmentation is a test of elision. It is designed to assess phonological processing at the level of word segments (syllables) and of letter sounds (phonemes).
{% endif %} {% if 567-repetition-nonsense-words-rn-score != undefined %}
Repetition Nonsense Words (RN)
{{ 567-repetition-nonsense-words-rn-score }}
This subtest is designed to assess phonological encoding and decoding.
{% endif %} {% if 568-speeded-naming-sn-score != undefined %}
Speeded Naming (SN)
{{ 568-speeded-naming-sn-score }}
This timed subtest is designed to assess rapid semantic access to and production of names of colors, shapes, sizes, letters, or numbers.
{% endif %} {% if 569-word-generation-wg-score != undefined %}
Word Generation (WG)
{{ 569-word-generation-wg-score }}
This subtest is designed to assess verbal productivity through the ability to generate words within specific semantic and initial letter categories.
{% endif %}
{% endif %} {% if 130-memory-and-learning == true %}
Memory and Learning

In this manual, the term learning refers to the acquisition of new information. Learning, as used here, is more general than is applied to the concept of a learning disability as it is not limited to the acquisition of new academic skills. Memory, as used here, is a more technical term describing the particular forms of acquisition and retrieval.

Subtest
Score
Description
{% if 571-list-memory-lm-list-memory-delayed-lmd-score != undefined %}
List Memory (LM) List Memory Delayed (LMD)
{{ 571-list-memory-lm-list-memory-delayed-lmd-score }}
This subtest is designed to assess verbal learning and memory, rate of learning, and the role of interference in recall for verbal material.
{% endif %} {% if 572-memory-for-designs-md-memory-for-designs-delayed-mdd-score != undefined %}
Memory for Designs (MD) Memory for Designs Delayed (MDD)
{{ 572-memory-for-designs-md-memory-for-designs-delayed-mdd-score }}
This subtest is designed to assess spatial memory for novel visual material.
{% endif %} {% if 573-memory-for-faces-mf-memory-for-faces-delayed-mfd-score != undefined %}
Memory for Faces (MF) Memory for Faces Delayed (MFD)
{{ 573-memory-for-faces-mf-memory-for-faces-delayed-mfd-score }}
This subtest is designed to assess encoding of facial features, as well as face discrimination and recognition.
{% endif %} {% if 574-memory-for-names-mn-memory-for-names-delayed-mnd-score != undefined %}
Memory for Names (MN) Memory for Names Delayed (MND)
{{ 574-memory-for-names-mn-memory-for-names-delayed-mnd-score }}
This subtest is designed to assess the ability to learn the names of children over three trials.
{% endif %} {% if 575-narrative-memory-nm-score != undefined %}
Narrative Memory (NM)
{{ 575-narrative-memory-nm-score }}
This subtest is designed to assess memory for organized verbal material under free recall, cued, recall, and recognition conditions.
{% endif %} {% if 576-sentence-repetition-sr-score != undefined %}
Sentence Repetition (SR)
{{ 576-sentence-repetition-sr-score }}
This subtest is designed to assess the ability to repeat sentences of increasing complexity and length.
{% endif %} {% if 577-word-list-interference-wi-score != undefined %}
Word List Interference (WI)
{{ 577-word-list-interference-wi-score }}
This subtest is designed to assess verbal working memory, repetition, and word recall following interference.
{% endif %}
{% endif %} {% if 131-sensorimotor == true %}
Sensorimotor

Sensorimotor functioning refers to the fact that motor control requires neural circuits connecting the motor guidance with sensory (e.g., kinesthetic, tactile, and visual) feedback.

Subtest
Score
Description
{% if 578-fingertip-tapping-ft-score != undefined %}
Fingertip Tapping (FT)
{{ 578-fingertip-tapping-ft-score }}
This timed subtest has two parts. The first part is designed to assess the child’s finger dexterity and motor speed. The second part is used to assess rapid motor programming.
{% endif %} {% if 579-imitating-hand-positions-ih-score != undefined %}
Imitating Hand Positions (IH)
{{ 579-imitating-hand-positions-ih-score }}
This subtest is designed to assess the ability to imitate hand/finger positions.
{% endif %} {% if 580-manual-motor-sequences-mm-score != undefined %}
Manual Motor Sequences (MM)
{{ 580-manual-motor-sequences-mm-score }}
This subtest is designed to assess the ability to imitate a series of rhythmic movement sequences using one or both hands.
{% endif %} {% if 581-visuomotor-precision-vp-score != undefined %}
Visuomotor Precision (VP)
{{ 581-visuomotor-precision-vp-score }}
This timed subtest is designed to assess graphomotor speed and accuracy.
{% endif %}
{% endif %} {% if 132-social-perception == true %}
Social Perception

The subcomponents of social perception assessed include facial affect recognition and the ability to comprehend others perspectives, intentions, and beliefs (i.e., theory of mind).

Subtest
Score
Description
{% if 582-affect-recognition-ar-score != undefined %}
Affect Recognition (AR)
{{ 582-affect-recognition-ar-score }}
This subtest is designed to assess the ability to recognize affect (happy, sad, anger, fear, disgust, and neutral) from photographs.
{% endif %} {% if 583-theory-of-mind-tm-score != undefined %}
Theory of Mind {TM}
{{ 583-theory-of-mind-tm-score }}
This subtest is designed to assess the ability to understand mental functions such as belief, intention, deception, emotion, imagination, and pretending, as well as the ability to understand that others have their own thoughts, ideas, and feelings that may be different from one’s own and the ability to understand how emotion relates to social context and to recognize the appropriate affect given various social contexts.
{% endif %}
{% endif %} {% if 133-visuospatial-processing == true %}
Visuospatial Processing

The subcomponents of visuospatial processing that are assessed include the ability to judge line.

Subtest
Score
Description
{% if 584-arrows-aw-score != undefined %}
Arrows (AW)
{{ 584-arrows-aw-score }}
This subtest is designed to assess the ability to judge line orientation.
{% endif %} {% if 585-block-construction-bc-score != undefined %}
Block Construction (BC)
{{ 585-block-construction-bc-score }}
This timed subtest is designed to assess the visuospatial and visuomotor ability to reproduce three-dimensional constructions from models or from two-dimensional drawings.
{% endif %} {% if 586-design-copying-dc-score != undefined %}
Design Copying (DC)
{{ 586-design-copying-dc-score }}
This subtest is designed to assess motor and visual-perceptual skills associated with the ability to copy two-dimensional geometric figures.
{% endif %} {% if 587-geometric-puzzles-gp-score != undefined %}
Geometric Puzzles (GP)
{{ 587-geometric-puzzles-gp-score }}
This subtest is designed to assess mental rotation, visuospatial analysis, and attention to detail.
{% endif %} {% if 588-picture-puzzles-pp-score != undefined %}
Picture Puzzles (PP)
{{ 588-picture-puzzles-pp-score }}
This subtest is designed to assess discrimination, spatial localization, and visual scanning, as well as the ability to deconstruct a picture into its constituent parts and recognize part-whole relationships.
{% endif %} {% if 589-route-finding-rf-score != undefined %}
Route Finding (RF)
{{ 589-route-finding-rf-score }}
This subtest is designed to assess knowledge of visual spatial relations and directionality, as well as the ability to use this knowledge to transfer a route from a simple schematic map to a more complex one.
{% endif %}
{% endif %}
{% endif %} {% if QIK-CPT == true %}

Academic Achievement

QIK Continuous Performance Test 

 QIK CPT

The QIK CPT is a digital continuous performance test that measures an individual's attention, impulsivity, response time, and variability in their performance. In general, continuous performance tasks assess one’s ability to sustain attention over time. (Client) was asked to press a button following the presentation of a target symbol and to inhibit (his/her) response when presented with a distractor symbol.

{% if 46-qik-cpt-accuracy-index != undefined or 46-qik-cpt-sustained-attention != undefined or 46-qik-cpt-impulse-control != undefined or 46-qik-cpt-performance-index != undefined or 46-qik-cpt-speed-of-response != undefined or 46-qik-cpt-consistency-of-response != undefined %}

{{ di-name }} received a score of {{ 46-qik-cpt-accuracy-index }} on the Accuracy Index ({{ 46-qik-cpt-sustained-attention }} Sustained Attention; {{ 46-qik-cpt-impulse-control }} Impulse Control), and a {{ 46-qik-cpt-performance-index }} on the Performance Index ({{ 46-qik-cpt-speed-of-response }} Speed of Response; {{ 46-qik-cpt-consistency-of-response }} Consistency of Response).

{% endif %}
{% endif %} {% if Vineland-II == true %}

Adpative Functioning

Vineland-II

Vineland-II is an individually administered measure of adaptive behavior for ages birth through 90.

{% if 52-communication-domain == true %}
Communication Domain
Subdomain
Score
Description
{% if 233-receptive-score != undefined %}
Receptive
{{ 233-receptive-score }}
How the individual listens and pays attention, and what he or she understands.
{% endif %} {% if 234-expressive-score != undefined %}
Expressive
{{ 234-expressive-score }}
What the individual says, how he or she uses words and sentences to gather and provide information.
{% endif %} {% if 235-written-score != undefined %}
Written
{{ 235-written-score }}
What the individual understands about how letters make words, and what he or she reads and writes.
{% endif %}

{% endif %} {% if 238-community-score != undefined %}
Community
{{ 238-community-score }}

{% endif %}
{% endif %} {% if ADOS-2 == true %}

Autism

The Autism Diagnostic Observation Schedule 2 

 ADOS-2

ADOS-2 is a semi-structured, standardized assessment of communication, social interaction, play/imaginative use of materials, and restricted and repetitive behaviors for individuals who have been referred because of possible autism spectrum disorders (ASD).

{% if 6-communication == true or 7-reciprocal-social-interaction == true or 8-restricted-and-repetitive-behaviors == true %}
Module 1

Module 1 is intended for children who do not consistently use phrase speech (i.e., the flexible use of non-echoed, three-word utterances that sometimes involve a verb and that are spontaneous, meaningful word combinations). Therefore, children receiving this module have speech abilities ranging from no speech at all up to and including the use of simple phrases. Module 1 is most appropriate for children aged 31 months and older.

Social Affect (SA)
{% if 6-communication == true %}
Communication
Subtest
Score
Description
{% if 17-frequency-of-spontaneous-vocalization-directed-to-others-a-2-score != undefined %}
Frequency of Spontaneous Vocalization Directed to Others (A-2)
{{ 17-frequency-of-spontaneous-vocalization-directed-to-others-a-2-score }}
The focus of this item is on the amount of spontaneous socially directed vocalizations.
{% endif %} {% if 18-pointing-a-7-score != undefined %}
Pointing (A-7)
{{ 18-pointing-a-7-score }}
The focus of this item is on socially purposeful, visually directed pointing, which includes pointing for the purpose of requesting and/or for shared attention.
{% endif %} {% if 19-gestures-a-8-score != undefined %}
Gestures (A-8)
{{ 19-gestures-a-8-score }}
This item pertains to the use of any kind of gesture other than pointing. Gestures may be conventional or idiosyncratic, but they must be communicative and cannot involve moving someone else’s body or touching/holding an object. Mannerisms are not included.
{% endif %}
{% endif %} {% if 7-reciprocal-social-interaction == true %}
Reciprocal Social Interaction
Subtest
Score
Description
{% if 20-unusual-eye-contact-b-1-score != undefined %}
Unusual Eye Contact (B-1)
{{ 20-unusual-eye-contact-b-1-score }}
The focus of this item is on clear, flexible, socially modulated, and appropriate gaze that is used for a variety of purposes. This is in contrast to gaze that is limited in flexibility, appropriateness, or contexts.
{% endif %} {% if 21-facial-expressions-directed-to-others-b-3-score != undefined %}
Facial Expressions Directed to Others (B-3)
{{ 21-facial-expressions-directed-to-others-b-3-score }}
The focus of this item is on whether the child’s facial expressions are directed to another person for the purpose of communicating affective (e.g., enjoyment, frustration) or cognitive (e.g., puzzlement, skepticism) sates. Facial expressions that are directed to objects or that are undirected are not evaluated here.
{% endif %} {% if 22-integration-of-gaze-and-other-behaviors-during-social-overtures-b-4-score != undefined %}
Integration of Gaze and Other Behaviors During Social Overtures (B-4)
{{ 22-integration-of-gaze-and-other-behaviors-during-social-overtures-b-4-score }}
The focus of this item is on the quality of the child’s attempts to initiate interaction, particularly the integration of gaze with other behaviors, not the frequency of initiations.
{% endif %} {% if 23-shared-enjoyment-in-interaction-b-5-score != undefined %}
Shared Enjoyment in Interaction (B-5)
{{ 23-shared-enjoyment-in-interaction-b-5-score }}
The focus of this item is on the child’s directed pleasure during any of the activities or presses. It does not indicate his or her general emotional state during the evaluation and applies to the child’s ability to indicate pleasure to the examiner, not just to interact or respond.
{% endif %} {% if 24-showing-b-9-score != undefined %}
Showing (B-9)
{{ 24-showing-b-9-score }}
Showing is defined as deliberately orienting or placing an object where it can be seen by another person with no identifiable purpose of getting help or participating in a routine. This must be accompanied by eye contact, but vocalization is not required.
{% endif %} {% if 25-spontaneous-initiation-of-joint-attention-b-10-score != undefined %}
Spontaneous Initiation of Joint Attention (B-10)
{{ 25-spontaneous-initiation-of-joint-attention-b-10-score }}
The focus of this item is on the child’s attempts to draw another person’s attention to objects that neither of them is touching and are clearly out of reach. This does not include such attempts if they are for the purpose of requesting.
{% endif %} {% if 26-response-to-joint-attention-b-11-score != undefined %}
Response to Joint Attention (B-11)
{{ 26-response-to-joint-attention-b-11-score }}
The focus of this item is on the child’s response to the examiner’s use of gaze and/or pointing to direct the child’s attention to a distant object.
{% endif %} {% if 27-quality-of-social-overtures-b-12-score != undefined %}
Quality of Social Overtures (B-12)
{{ 27-quality-of-social-overtures-b-12-score }}
This is a summary item that focuses on the quality of the child’s attempts to initiate social interaction, not on the frequency of such attempts.
{% endif %}
{% endif %} {% if 8-restricted-and-repetitive-behaviors == true %}
Restricted and Repetitive Behavior (RRB)
Restricted and Repetitive Behaviors
Subtest
Score
Description
{% if 28-intonation-of-vocalizations-or-verbalizations-a-3-score != undefined %}
Intonation of Vocalizations or Verbalizations (A-3)
{{ 28-intonation-of-vocalizations-or-verbalizations-a-3-score }}
This is a general item that applies to all vocalizations or verbalizations, including crying and whining.
{% endif %} {% if 29-stereotyped-idiosyncratic-use-of-words-or-phrases-a-5-score != undefined %}
Stereotyped/Idiosyncratic Use of Words or Phrases (A-5)
{{ 29-stereotyped-idiosyncratic-use-of-words-or-phrases-a-5-score }}
The focus of this item is on the stereotyped or idiosyncratic quality of the phrasing, unusual use of words or formation of utterances, and/or their arbitrary association with a particular meaning.
{% endif %} {% if 30-unusual-sensory-interest-in-play-material-person-d-1-score != undefined %}
Unusual Sensory Interest in Play Material/Person (D-1)
{{ 30-unusual-sensory-interest-in-play-material-person-d-1-score }}
The focus of this item is on the child’s interest in or unusual behaviors associated with sensory aspects of toys or surroundings (e.g., sniffing, repetitive feeling of texture, licking, mouthing, or biting, unusually strong interest in the repetition of certain sounds, unusual or prolonged visual examination).
{% endif %} {% if 31-hand-and-finger-and-other-complex-mannerisms-d-2-score != undefined %}
Hand and Finger and Other Complex Mannerisms (D-2)
{{ 31-hand-and-finger-and-other-complex-mannerisms-d-2-score }}
The focus of this item is on unusual and/or repetitive movements or posturing of the hands and fingers, arms, or body. This does not include repetitive clapping, finger tapping, nail biting, hair twisting, and thumb sucking.
{% endif %} {% if 32-unusually-repetitive-interests-or-stereotyped-behaviors-d-4-score != undefined %}
Unusually Repetitive Interests or Stereotyped Behaviors (D-4)
{{ 32-unusually-repetitive-interests-or-stereotyped-behaviors-d-4-score }}
The focus of this item is on any unusually repetitive interests or stereotyped behaviors, including preoccupation with unusual activities or objects, repetitive nonfunctional use of toys, repetitive actions, and insistence on having the parent/caregiver or examiner act in a specific way.
{% endif %}
{% endif %} {% endif %} {% if 9-communication == true or 10-reciprocal-social-interaction == true or 11-restricted-and-repetitive-behaviors == true %}
Module 2

Module 2 is intended for children of any age who use phrase speech (i.e., the flexible use of non-echoed, three-word utterances that sometimes involve a verb and that are spontaneous, meaningful word combinations) but who are not yet verbally fluent (i.e., producing a range of flexible sentence types, providing language beyond the immediate context, and describing logical connections within a sentence).

{% if 9-communication == true %}
Social Affect (SA)
Communication
Subtest
Score
Description
{% if 33-pointing-a-6-score != undefined %}
Pointing (A-6)
{{ 33-pointing-a-6-score }}
The focus of this item is on social purposeful, visually directed pointing primarily to express interest (rather than to request).
{% endif %} {% if 34-descriptive-conventional-instrumental-or-informational-gestures-a-7-score != undefined %}
Descriptive, Conventional, Instrumental, or Informational Gestures (A-7)
{{ 34-descriptive-conventional-instrumental-or-informational-gestures-a-7-score }}
The focus of this item is on descriptive gestures that enact or represent an object or event (such as acting out rinsing a toothbrush or showing how a roller coaster curves through the air).
{% endif %}
{% endif %} {% if 10-reciprocal-social-interaction == true %}
Reciprocal Social Interaction
