{% endif %} {% if 36-facial-expressions-directed-to-others-b-2-score != undefined %}
Facial Expressions Directed to Others (B-2)
{{ 36-facial-expressions-directed-to-others-b-2-score }}
The focus of this item is on whether the child’s facial expressions are directed to another person for the purpose of communicating affective (e.g., enjoyment, frustration) or cognitive (e.g., puzzlement, skepticism) sates. Facial expressions that are directed to objects or that are undirected are not evaluated here.
{% endif %} {% if 37-shared-enjoyment-in-interaction-b-3-score != undefined %}
Shared Enjoyment in Interaction (B-3)
{{ 37-shared-enjoyment-in-interaction-b-3-score }}
The focus of this item is on the child’s directed pleasure during any of the activities or presses. It does not indicate his or her general emotional state during the evaluation and applies to the child’s ability to indicate pleasure to the examiner, not just to interact or respond.
{% endif %} {% if 38-showing-b-5-score != undefined %}
Showing (B-5)
{{ 38-showing-b-5-score }}
Showing is defined as deliberately orienting or placing an object where it can be seen by another person with no identifiable purpose of getting help or participating in a routine. This must be accompanied by eye contact, but vocalization is not required.
{% endif %} {% if 39-spontaneous-initiation-of-joint-attention-b-6-score != undefined %}
Spontaneous Initiation of Joint Attention (B-6)
{{ 39-spontaneous-initiation-of-joint-attention-b-6-score }}
The focus of this item is on the child’s attempts to draw another person’s attention to objects that neither of them is touching and are clearly out of reach. This does not include such attempts if they are for the purpose of requesting.
{% endif %} {% if 40-quality-of-social-overtures-b-8-score != undefined %}
Quality of Social Overtures (B-8)
{{ 40-quality-of-social-overtures-b-8-score }}
This is a summary item that focuses on the quality of the child’s attempts to initiate social interaction with the examiner, not on the frequency of such attempts.
{% endif %} {% if 41-amount-of-reciprocal-social-communication-b-11-score != undefined %}
Amount of Reciprocal Social Communication (B-11)
{{ 41-amount-of-reciprocal-social-communication-b-11-score }}
The focus of this item is on the frequency with which reciprocal interchanges occur during the course of the ADOS-2 evaluation, using any mode of communication. Frequency here is defined both by absolute number of occurrences and distribution across a range of contexts.
{% endif %} {% if 42-overall-quality-of-rapport-b-12-score != undefined %}
Overall Quality of Rapport (B-12)
{{ 42-overall-quality-of-rapport-b-12-score }}
This item is a summary rating that reflects the examiner’s overall judgment of the rapport established with the child during the ADOS-2 evaluation. It particularly concerns the degree to which the examiner had to modify his or her own behavior to maintain the interaction successfully.
{% endif %}
{% endif %} {% if 11-restricted-and-repetitive-behaviors == true %}
Restricted and Repetitive Behavior (RRB)
Restricted and Repetitive Behaviors
Subtest
Score
Description
{% if 43-stereotyped-idiosyncratic-use-of-words-or-phrases-a-4-score != undefined %}
Stereotyped/Idiosyncratic Use of Words or Phrases (A-4)
{{ 43-stereotyped-idiosyncratic-use-of-words-or-phrases-a-4-score }}
The focus of this item is on the stereotyped or idiosyncratic quality of the phrasing, unusual use of words or formation of utterances, and/or their arbitrary association with a particular meaning.
{% endif %} {% if 44-unusual-sensory-interest-in-play-material-person-d-1-score != undefined %}
Unusual Sensory Interest in Play Material/Person (D-1)
{{ 44-unusual-sensory-interest-in-play-material-person-d-1-score }}
The focus of this item is on the child’s interest in or unusual behaviors associated with sensory aspects of toys or surroundings (e.g., sniffing, repetitive feeling of texture, licking, mouthing, or biting, unusually strong interest in the repetition of certain sounds, unusual or prolonged visual examination).
{% endif %} {% if 45-hand-and-finger-and-other-complex-mannerisms-d-2-score != undefined %}
Inconsistency IndexHand and Finger and Other Complex Mannerisms (D-2)
{{ 45-hand-and-finger-and-other-complex-mannerisms-d-2-score }}
The focus of this item is on unusual and/or repetitive movements or posturing of the hands and fingers, arms, or body. This does not include repetitive clapping, finger tapping, nail biting, hair twisting, and thumb sucking.
{% endif %} {% if 46-unusually-repetitive-interests-or-stereotyped-behaviors-score != undefined %}
Unusually Repetitive Interests or Stereotyped Behaviors
{{ 46-unusually-repetitive-interests-or-stereotyped-behaviors-score }}
The focus of this item is on any unusually repetitive interests or stereotyped behaviors, including preoccupation with unusual activities or objects, repetitive nonfunctional use of toys, repetitive actions, and insistence on having the parent/caregiver or examiner act in a specific way.
{% endif %}
{% endif %} {% endif %} {% if 12-communication == true or 13-reciprocal-social-interaction == true or 14-restricted-and-repetitive-behaviors == true %}
Module 3

Module 3 is intended for individuals who are verbally fluent. Verbal fluency is broadly defined in this context as language development equivalent to (or higher than) the expressive language skills of a typical 4-year-old child: producing a range of flexible sentence types and grammatical forms, using language to provide information about events out of the immediate context, and producing some logical connections within sentences (e.g., using but or though), although the individual may make some grammatical errors. Module 3 is best suited for verbally fluent children and adolescents for whom playing with action figure-type toys is age appropriate (usually under 16 years of age).

{% if 12-communication == true %}
Social Affect (SA)
Communication
Subtest
Score
Description
{% if 47-reporting-of-events-a-7-score != undefined %}
Reporting of Events (A-7)
{{ 47-reporting-of-events-a-7-score }}
The focus of this item is on the participant’s ability to select an event spontaneously or in response to the examiner’s general questioning and to describe it in a comprehensible fashion without requiring specific probes. This should involve a sequential description of an event outside the immediate environment.
{% endif %} {% if 48-conversation-a-8-score != undefined %}
Conversation (A-8)
{{ 48-conversation-a-8-score }}
This is a summary item that focuses on the to-and-fro use of words and phrases in social conversation.
{% endif %} {% if 49-descriptive-conventional-instrumental-or-informational-gestures-a-9-score != undefined %}
Descriptive, Conventional, Instrumental, or Informational Gestures (A-9)
{{ 49-descriptive-conventional-instrumental-or-informational-gestures-a-9-score }}
Academic struggles. May have difficulty learning and/or remembering concepts. May need extra instructions. May have executive functioning deficits
{% endif %}
{% endif %} {% if 13-reciprocal-social-interaction == true %}
Reciprocal Social Interaction
Subtest
Score
Description
{% if 50-unusual-eye-contact-b-1-score != undefined %}
Unusual Eye Contact (B-1)
{{ 50-unusual-eye-contact-b-1-score }}
The focus of this item is on clear, flexible, socially modulated, and appropriate gaze that is used for a variety of purposes. This is in contrast to gaze that is limited in flexibility, appropriateness, or contexts.
{% endif %} {% if 51-facial-expressions-directed-to-examiner-b-2-score != undefined %}
Facial Expressions Directed to Examiner (B-2)
{{ 51-facial-expressions-directed-to-examiner-b-2-score }}
The focus of this item is on whether the child’s facial expressions are directed to the examiner for the purpose of communicating affective (e.g., enjoyment, frustration) or cognitive (e.g., puzzlement, skepticism) sates. Facial expressions that are directed to objects, other people in the room, or that are undirected are not evaluated here.
{% endif %} {% if 52-shared-enjoyment-in-interaction-b-3-score != undefined %}
Shared Enjoyment in Interaction (B-3)
{{ 52-shared-enjoyment-in-interaction-b-3-score }}
The focus of this item is on the child’s directed pleasure during any of the activities or presses. It does not indicate his or her general emotional state during the evaluation and applies to the child’s ability to indicate pleasure to the examiner, not just to interact or respond.
{% endif %} {% if 53-shared-enjoyment-in-interaction-b-4-score != undefined %}
Shared Enjoyment in Interaction (B-4)
{{ 53-shared-enjoyment-in-interaction-b-4-score }}
The focus of this item is on the participant’s directed pleasure during any of the tasks or conversation. This item is not used to indicate his or her general emotional state during the ADOS-2 evaluation. The rating applies to the participant’s ability to indicate pleasure to the examiner, not just to interact or respond.
{% endif %} {% if 54-quality-of-social-overtures-b-7-score != undefined %}
Quality of Social Overtures (B-7)
{{ 54-quality-of-social-overtures-b-7-score }}
This is a summary item that focuses on the quality of the child’s attempts to initiate social interaction with the examiner, not on the frequency of such attempts. Special attention is given to the form of the overture and its appropriateness to the social context.
{% endif %} {% if 55-quality-of-social-response-b-9-score != undefined %}
Quality of Social Response (B-9)
{{ 55-quality-of-social-response-b-9-score }}
This is a summary item that focuses on the participant’s social responses throughout the ADOS-2 evaluation.
{% endif %} {% if 56-amount-of-reciprocal-social-communication-b-10-score != undefined %}
Amount of Reciprocal Social Communication (B-10)
{{ 56-amount-of-reciprocal-social-communication-b-10-score }}
The focus of this item is on the frequency with which reciprocal interchanges occur during the course of the ADOS-2 evaluation, using any mode of communication. Frequency here is defined both by absolute number of occurrences and distribution across a range of contexts.
{% endif %} {% if 57-overall-quality-of-rapport-b-11-score != undefined %}
Overall Quality of Rapport (B-11)
{{ 57-overall-quality-of-rapport-b-11-score }}
This item is a summary rating that reflects the examiner’s overall judgment of the rapport established with the child during the ADOS-2 evaluation. It particularly concerns the degree to which the examiner had to modify his or her own behavior to maintain the interaction successfully.
{% endif %}
{% endif %} {% if 14-restricted-and-repetitive-behaviors == true %}
Restricted and Repetitive Behavior (RRB)
Restricted and Repetitive Behaviors
Subtest
Score
Description
{% if 58-stereotyped-idiosyncratic-use-of-words-or-phrases-a-4-score != undefined %}
Stereotyped/Idiosyncratic Use of Words or Phrases (A-4)
{{ 58-stereotyped-idiosyncratic-use-of-words-or-phrases-a-4-score }}
The focus of this item is on the stereotyped or idiosyncratic quality of the phrasing, unusual use of words or formation of utterances, and/or their arbitrary association with a particular meaning.
{% endif %} {% if 59-unusual-sensory-interest-in-play-material-person-d-1-score != undefined %}
Unusual Sensory Interest in Play Material/Person (D-1)
{{ 59-unusual-sensory-interest-in-play-material-person-d-1-score }}
The focus of this item is on the child’s interest in or unusual behaviors associated with sensory aspects of toys or surroundings (e.g., sniffing, repetitive feeling of texture, licking, mouthing, or biting, unusually strong interest in the repetition of certain sounds, unusual or prolonged visual examination).
{% endif %} {% if 60-hand-and-finger-and-other-complex-mannerisms-d-2-score != undefined %}
Hand and Finger and Other Complex Mannerisms (D-2)
{{ 60-hand-and-finger-and-other-complex-mannerisms-d-2-score }}
The focus of this item is on unusual and/or repetitive movements or posturing of the hands and fingers, arms, or body. This does not include repetitive clapping, finger tapping, nail biting, hair twisting, and thumb sucking.
{% endif %} {% if 61-unusually-repetitive-interests-or-stereotyped-behaviors-score != undefined %}
Unusually Repetitive Interests or Stereotyped Behaviors
{{ 61-unusually-repetitive-interests-or-stereotyped-behaviors-score }}
The focus of this item is on any unusually repetitive interests or stereotyped behaviors, including preoccupation with unusual activities or objects, repetitive nonfunctional use of toys, repetitive actions, and insistence on having the parent/caregiver or examiner act in a specific way.
{% endif %}
{% endif %} {% endif %} {% if 15-communication == true or 16-reciprocal-social-interaction == true %}
Module 4

Module 4 is intended for individuals who are verbally fluent Verbal fluency is broadly defined in this context as language development equivalent to (or higher than) the expressive language skills of a typical 4-year-old child: producing a range of flexible sentence types and grammatical forms, using language to provide information about events out of the immediate context, and producing some logical connections within sentences (e.g., using but or though), although the individual may make some grammatical errors. Module 4 is best suited for verbally fluent older adolescent and adults.

{% if 15-communication == true %}
Social Affect (SA)
Communication
Subtest
Score
Description
{% if 62-stereotyped-idiosyncratic-use-of-words-or-phrases-a-4-score != undefined %}
Stereotyped/Idiosyncratic Use of Words or Phrases (A-4)
{{ 62-stereotyped-idiosyncratic-use-of-words-or-phrases-a-4-score }}
The focus of this item is on the stereotyped or idiosyncratic quality of the phrasing, unusual use of words or formation of utterances, and/or their arbitrary association with a particular meaning.
{% endif %} {% if 63-conversation-a-8-score != undefined %}
Conversation (A-8)
{{ 63-conversation-a-8-score }}
This is a summary item that focuses on the to-and-fro use of words and phrases in social conversation.
{% endif %} {% if 64-descriptive-conventional-instrumental-or-informational-gestures-a-9-score != undefined %}
Descriptive, Conventional, Instrumental, or Informational Gestures (A-9)
{{ 64-descriptive-conventional-instrumental-or-informational-gestures-a-9-score }}
The focus of this item is on descriptive gestures that enact or represent an object or event (such as acting out rinsing a toothbrush or showing how a roller coaster curves through the air).
{% endif %} {% if 65-emphatic-or-emotional-gestures-a-10-score != undefined %}
Emphatic or Emotional Gestures (A-10)
{{ 65-emphatic-or-emotional-gestures-a-10-score }}
The focus of this item is on emphatic (i.e., natural, rhythmic “beats” that often accompany speech) or emotional gestures (e.g., hand to mouth or hands up for “wow”).
{% endif %}
{% endif %} {% if 16-reciprocal-social-interaction == true %}
Reciprocal Social Interaction
Subtest
Score
Description
{% if 66-unusual-eye-contact-b-1-score != undefined %}
Unusual Eye Contact (B-1)
{{ 66-unusual-eye-contact-b-1-score }}
The focus of this item is on clear, flexible, socially modulated, and appropriate gaze that is used for a variety of purposes. This is in contrast to gaze that is limited in flexibility, appropriateness, or contexts.
{% endif %} {% if 68-comments-on-others-emotions-empathy-b-6-score != undefined %}
Facial Expressions Directed to Examiner (B-2)
{{ 68-comments-on-others-emotions-empathy-b-6-score }}
The focus of this item is on whether the child’s facial expressions are directed to the examiner for the purpose of communicating affective (e.g., enjoyment, frustration) or cognitive (e.g., puzzlement, skepticism) sates. Facial expressions that are directed to objects, other people in the room, or that are undirected are not evaluated here.
{% endif %} {% if 69-responsibility-b-8-score != undefined %}
Shared Enjoyment in Interaction (B-3)
{{ 69-responsibility-b-8-score }}
The focus of this item is on the child’s directed pleasure during any of the activities or presses. It does not indicate his or her general emotional state during the evaluation and applies to the child’s ability to indicate pleasure to the examiner, not just to interact or respond.
{% endif %} {% if 70-quality-of-social-overtures-b-9-score != undefined %}
Shared Enjoyment in Interaction (B-4)
{{ 70-quality-of-social-overtures-b-9-score }}
The focus of this item is on the participant’s directed pleasure during any of the tasks or conversation. This item is not used to indicate his or her general emotional state during the ADOS-2 evaluation. The rating applies to the participant’s ability to indicate pleasure to the examiner, not just to interact or respond.
{% endif %} {% if 67-facial-expressions-directed-to-examiner-b-2-score != undefined %}
Quality of Social Overtures (B-7)
{{ 67-facial-expressions-directed-to-examiner-b-2-score }}
This is a summary item that focuses on the quality of the child’s attempts to initiate social interaction with the examiner, not on the frequency of such attempts. Special attention is given to the form of the overture and its appropriateness to the social context.
{% endif %} {% if 71-quality-of-social-response-b-11-score != undefined %}
Quality of Social Response (B-9)
{{ 71-quality-of-social-response-b-11-score }}
This is a summary item that focuses on the participant’s social responses throughout the ADOS-2 evaluation.
{% endif %} {% if 72-amount-of-reciprocal-social-communication-b-12-score != undefined %}
Amount of Reciprocal Social Communication (B-10)
{{ 72-amount-of-reciprocal-social-communication-b-12-score }}
The focus of this item is on the frequency with which reciprocal interchanges occur during the course of the ADOS-2 evaluation, using any mode of communication. Frequency here is defined both by absolute number of occurrences and distribution across a range of contexts.
{% endif %}
{% endif %} {% endif %}
{% endif %} {% if CARS-2 == true %}

Autism

Childhood Autism Rating Scale - 2 

 CARS-2

The CARS-2 identifies individuals with autism, based on direct observation. It discriminates between autism and severe cognitive deficits. This new edition is also more responsive to those on the high-functioning end of the spectrum. The Standard Version Rating Booklet and the High-Functioning Version Rating Booklet each address 15 functional areas.

A questionnaire for Parents or Caregivers is also included. The CARS2-QPC is an unscored form completed by the parent or caregiver of the individual being assessed. Its purpose is to give the clinician more information on which to base CARS2-ST or CARS2-HF ratings. The areas covered by the CARS2-QPC include the individuals early development; social, emotional, and communication skills; repetitive behaviors; play and routines; and unusual sensory interests.

{% if 22-cars-2-st-items == true %}
CARS-2-ST
CARS-2-ST Items
Item
Score
Description
{% if 98-relating-to-people-score != undefined %}
Relating to People
{{ 98-relating-to-people-score }}
This is a rating of how the child behaves in a variety of situations involving interaction with other people.
{% endif %} {% if 99-imitation-score != undefined %}
Imitation
{{ 99-imitation-score }}
This rating is based on how the child imitates both verbal and nonverbal acts. Behavior to be imitated should clearly be within the child’s abilities.
{% endif %} {% if 100-emotional-response-score != undefined %}
Emotional Response
{{ 100-emotional-response-score }}
This is a rating of how the child reacts to both pleasant and unpleasant situations. It involves a determination of whether the child’s emotions or feelings seem appropriate to the situation. This items in concerned with the appropriateness of both the type of response and the intensity of the response.
{% endif %} {% if 101-body-use-score != undefined %}
Body Use
{{ 101-body-use-score }}
This area represents a rating of both coordination and appropriateness of body movements. It includes such deviations as posturing, spinning, tapping, rocking, toe-walking, and self-directed aggression.
{% endif %} {% if 102-object-use-score != undefined %}
Object Use
{{ 102-object-use-score }}
This is a rating of both the child’s interest in toys or other objects, and his or her uses of them.
{% endif %} {% if 103-adaption-to-change-score != undefined %}
Adaption to Change
{{ 103-adaption-to-change-score }}
This item concerns difficulties in changing established routines or patterns and in changing from one activity to another.
{% endif %} {% if 104-visual-response-score != undefined %}
Visual Response
{{ 104-visual-response-score }}
This is a rating of unusual visual attention patterns found in many individuals on the autism spectrum. This rating includes the child’s response when he or she is required to look at objects or material.
{% endif %} {% if 105-listening-response-score != undefined %}
Listening Response
{{ 105-listening-response-score }}
This is a rating of unusual listening behavior or unusual responses to sounds. It involves the child’s reaction to both human voices and other types of sound. This item is also concerned with the child’s interest in various sounds.
{% endif %} {% if 106-taste-smell-and-touch-response-and-use-score != undefined %}
Taste, Smell, and Touch Response and Use
{{ 106-taste-smell-and-touch-response-and-use-score }}
This is a rating of the child’s response to stimulation of the taste, smell, and touch senses (including pain). It is also a rating of whether the child makes appropriate use of these sense modalities. In contract to the “distance” senses of hearing and vision rated in the previous two areas, this is a rating of the “near” senses.
{% endif %} {% if 107-fear-or-nervousness-score != undefined %}
Fear or Nervousness
{{ 107-fear-or-nervousness-score }}
This is a rating of unusual or unexplainable fears. However, it also includes rating the absence of fear under conditions where a typically developing child at the same developmental level would be likely to show fear or nervousness.
{% endif %} {% if 108-verbal-communication-score != undefined %}
Verbal Communication
{{ 108-verbal-communication-score }}
This is a rating of all facets of the child’s use of speech and language assess not only the presence or absence of speech but also the peculiarity, bizarreness, or inappropriateness of all elements of the child’s utterances when speech is present. Thus, when speech of any sort is present, assess the child’s vocabulary and sentence structure; the tonal quality, volume or loudness, and rhythm of utterances; and the situation appropriateness of the content of meaning of the child’s speech.
{% endif %} {% if 109-nonverbal-communication-score != undefined %}
Nonverbal Communication
{{ 109-nonverbal-communication-score }}
This is a rating of the child’s nonverbal communication through the use of facial expression, posture, gesture, and body movement. It also includes the child’s response to the nonverbal communication of others. If the child has reasonably good verbal communication skills, there may be less of nonverbal communication; however, a child with impairments of verbal communication may or may not have developed a nonverbal means of communication.
{% endif %} {% if 110-activity-level-score != undefined %}
Activity Level
{{ 110-activity-level-score }}
This rating refers to how much the child moves about in both restricted and unrestricted situations. Either overactivity or lethargy are part of this rating.
{% endif %} {% if 111-level-and-consistency-of-intellectual-response-score != undefined %}
Level and Consistency of Intellectual Response
{{ 111-level-and-consistency-of-intellectual-response-score }}
This rating is concerned both with the child’s general level of intellectual functioning and with the consistency or evenness of functioning from one type of skill to another. Some fluctuations in mental functioning occur in many typical children or in those with other problems besides autism. However, this area is intended to identify extremely unusual or “peak” skills.
{% endif %} {% if 112-general-impressions-score != undefined %}
General Impressions
{{ 112-general-impressions-score }}
This is intended to be an overall rating of autism based on your subjective impression of the degree to which the child has autism as defined by the other 14 items. This rating should be made without recourse to averaging the other ratings. In making this rating, you should take into account all available information concerning the child, including information from such sources as the case history, parent interviews, or past records.
{% endif %}
{% endif %} {% if 23-cars-2-hf-items == true %}
CARS-2-HF
CARS-2-HF Items
Item
Score
Description
{% if 113-social-emotional-understanding-score != undefined %}
Social-Emotional Understanding
{{ 113-social-emotional-understanding-score }}
Social-emotional understanding addresses an individual’s cognitive understanding of others’ communication, behaviors, and differing perspectives. The dimensions of social understanding that are included in this item are the ability to read the nonverbal cues of others and the ability to take another person’s perspective. This item does not reflect whether someone has friends or is in a relationship. Rather it deals with an individual’s ability to perceive and articulate how another person may feel or what his or her perspective may be in a situation.
{% endif %} {% if 114-emotional-expression-and-regulation-of-emotions-score != undefined %}
Emotional Expression and Regulation of Emotions
{{ 114-emotional-expression-and-regulation-of-emotions-score }}
This rating is based on the individual’s ability to express and regulate his or her own emotions.
{% endif %} {% if 115-relating-to-people-score != undefined %}
Relating to People
{{ 115-relating-to-people-score }}
This is a rating of how the individual behaves in a variety of situations involving interaction with other people. This item is related to the first two items, which also rate aspects of social relationships. This item differs in that it is confined to dimensions related to direct interpersonal interactions, and the person’s initiation of interactions and reaction to another individual. The two dimensions that are rated on this item are the individual’s initiation of interactions and the reciprocal nature of the interactions.
{% endif %} {% if 116-body-use-score != undefined %}
Body Use
{{ 116-body-use-score }}
This area represents both coordination and appropriateness of body movements. Subtle forms of fine and gross motor coordination are rated here, as well as deviations such as posturing, spinning, tapping and rocking, toe-walking, and self-directed aggression.
{% endif %} {% if 117-object-use-in-play-score != undefined %}
Object Use in Play
{{ 117-object-use-in-play-score }}
This rating includes the person’s interest in and use of toys or other objects. In addition to the traditional issues related to repetitive play with part of objects, the focus of this item also includes the degree to which the individual engages in imaginative symbolic play and the degree to which toy figures are used as agents.
{% endif %} {% if 118-visual-response-score != undefined %}
Visual Response
{{ 118-visual-response-score }}
This item covers the use of vision in three areas; visual fascinations, the ease with which the individual can shift visual attention, and the degree to which the individual’s eye contact is integrated with actions and communication.
{% endif %} {% if 119-listening-response-score != undefined %}
Listening Response
{{ 119-listening-response-score }}
This rating is based on the person’s unusual responses to sounds and how the listening response is coordinated with the use of other senses.
{% endif %} {% if 646-adaptation-to-change-restricted-interests-score != undefined %}
Adaptation to Change/Restricted Interests
{{ 646-adaptation-to-change-restricted-interests-score }}
This area concerns difficulty in changing established routines or patterns, difficulties in changing from one activity to another, and restricted special interests.
{% endif %}
{% endif %}
{% endif %} {% if GARS-3 == true %}

Autism

Gilliam Autism Rating Scale 

 GARS-3

GARS-3 The Gilliam Autism Rating Scale is a norm-referenced screening instrument used to identify individuals 3-22 years of age who have severe behavioral problems that may be indicative of an autism spectrum disorder. The GARS-3 is composed of 58 clearly stated items divided into six subscales that describe specific, observable, and measurable behaviors.

Subscale
Score
Description
{% if 215-restrictive-repetitive-behaviors-score != undefined %}
Restrictive/Repetitive Behaviors
{{ 215-restrictive-repetitive-behaviors-score }}
Measures stereotyped behaviors, fixed interests, routines, or rituals.
{% endif %} {% if 216-social-interaction-score != undefined %}
Social Interaction
{{ 216-social-interaction-score }}
Measures social behaviors.
{% endif %} {% if 217-social-communication-score != undefined %}
Social Communication
{{ 217-social-communication-score }}
Measures the individual’s responses to social situations and understanding of the intent of social interaction and communication.
{% endif %} {% if 218-emotional-responses-score != undefined %}
Emotional Responses
{{ 218-emotional-responses-score }}
Measures extreme emotional responses to everyday situations.
{% endif %} {% if 219-cognitive-style-score != undefined %}
Cognitive Style
{{ 219-cognitive-style-score }}
Measures idiosyncratic fixated interests, characteristics, and cognitive abilities.
{% endif %} {% if 220-maladaptive-speech-score != undefined %}
Maladaptive Speech
{{ 220-maladaptive-speech-score }}
Consists of items that describe deficits and idiosyncrasies in verbal communication.
{% endif %}
The Autism Index

The Autism Index measures composite performance by summing the scaled scores for each subscale. In most cases, this will include all six subscales. However, if a person is noncommunicative, the Cognitive Skills and Maladaptive Speech subscales cannot be fully completed. When this occurs, a reliable and valid Autism Index score can be determined by summing the scaled scores for the four subscales that were completed.

Guidelines for Interpreting Autism Index Scores

Autism Index
<= 54
55-70
71-100
>= 101
Probability of ASD
Unlikely
Probable
Very likely
Very likely
DSM-5 Severity Level for ASD
 
Level 1
Level 2
Level 3
Descriptor
Not ASD
Minimal Support Required
Requiring Substantial Support
Requiring Very Substantial Support
{% endif %} {% if WISC-V == true %}

INTELLIGENCE

Wechsler Intelligence Scale for Children 5 

 WISC-V

Wechsler Intelligence Scale for Children – Fifth Edition is a test of intellectual abilities, which assesses both cognitive strengths and weaknesses in children aged 6 years 0 months through 16 years 11 months (6:0-16:11).

Full Scale IQ

is a composite score that represents general intellectual functioning and is calculated from all of the subtests within the five main indices: Verbal Comprehension, Visual Spatial, Fluid Reasoning, Working Memory and Processing Speed

{% if 1-if-fsiq-is-meaningful == true %}

Overall, {{ di-name }} demonstrated a consistent performance on the WISC-V and received a Full-Scale IQ (FSIQ) score of {{ 1-wisc-v-fsiq-score }} ({{ 1-wisc-v-fsiq-percentile }} percentile), which falls within in the {{ 1-wisc-v-fsiq-rank }} range when compared to {% if di-gender == 'Boy' %} his {% else %} her {% endif %} same-aged peers.

{% else %}

Overall, {{ di-name }} demonstrated an inconsistent performance on the WISC-V. As a result, {% if di-gender == 'Boy' %} his {% else %} her {% endif %} Full-Scale score cannot be interpreted meaningfully due to the significant discrepancies between the five Composite areas that constitute {% if di-gender == 'Boy' %} his {% else %} her {% endif %} Full-Scale score (FSIQ). Therefore, in order to better understand {% if di-gender == 'Boy' %} his {% else %} her {% endif %} cognitive strengths and weaknesses, a more in-depth look at all of {{ di-name }}'s individual subtest scores is warranted.

GENERAL ABILITY INDEX

is a composite score that provides an estimate of general intellectual ability, with reduced emphasis on working memory and processing speed relative to the FSIQ. Client scored a {{ 2-WISC-V-gai-score }}.

{% endif %}
{% if 1-verbal-comprehension == true or 2-visual-spatial == true or 5-processing-speed == true %}

Intellectual Functioning

Full Scale
{% endif %} {% if 1-verbal-comprehension == true %}
VERBAL COMPREHENSION
Subtest
Score
Description
{% if 1-similarities-score != undefined %}
Similarities
{{ 1-similarities-score }}
The subtest is designed to measure verbal concept formation and abstract reasoning. It also involves crystallized intelligence, word knowledge, cognitive flexibility, auditory comprehension, long-term memory, associative and categorical thinking, distinction between nonessential and essential features, and verbal expression.
{% endif %} {% if 2-vocabulary-score != undefined %}
Vocabulary
{{ 2-vocabulary-score }}
The subtest is designed to measure word knowledge and verbal concept formation. It also measures crystallized intelligence, fund of knowledge, learning ability, verbal expression, long-term memory, and degree of vocabulary development.
{% endif %} {% if 3-information-score != undefined %}
Information
{{ 3-information-score }}
This subtest is designed to measure a child’s ability to acquire, retain, and retrieve general factual knowledge. It involves crystallized intelligence, long-term memory, and the ability to retain and retrieve knowledge from the environment and/or formal instruction.
{% endif %} {% if 4-comprehension-score != undefined %}
Comprehension
{{ 4-comprehension-score }}
It is designed to measure verbal reasoning and conceptualization, verbal comprehension and expression, the ability to evaluate and use past experience, and the ability to demonstrate practical knowledge and judgement. It also involved crystallized intelligence, knowledge of conventional standards of behavior, social judgement, long-term memory and common sense.
{% endif %}
{% endif %} {% if 2-visual-spatial == true %}
VISUAL SPATIAL
Subtest
Score
Description
{% if 5-block-design-score != undefined %}
Block Design
{{ 5-block-design-score }}
The subtest is designed to measure verbal concept formation and abstract reasoning. It also involves crystallized intelligence, word knowledge, cognitive flexibility, auditory comprehension, long-term memory, associative and categorical thinking, distinction between nonessential and essential features, and verbal expression.
{% endif %} {% if 6-vocabulary-score != undefined %}
Vocabulary
{{ 6-vocabulary-score }}
The subtest is designed to measure the ability to analyze and synthesize abstract visual stimuli. It also involved nonverbal concept formation and reasoning, broad visual intelligence, visual perception and organization, simultaneous processing, visual-motor coordination, learning, and the ability to separate figure-ground in visual stimuli.
{% endif %}
{% endif %} {% if 5-processing-speed == true %}
PROCESSING SPEED
Subtest
Score
Description
{% if 14-coding-score != undefined %}
Coding
{{ 14-coding-score }}
This subtest measures processing speed, short-term visual memory, procedural and incidental learning ability, psychomotor speed, visual perception, visual-motor coordination, visual scanning ability, cognitive flexibility, attention, concentration, and motivation.
{% endif %} {% if 15-symbol-search-score != undefined %}
Symbol Search
{{ 15-symbol-search-score }}
It involves visual-perceptual and decision-making speed, short-term visual memory, visual-motor coordination, inhibitory control, visual discrimination, psychomotor speed, sustained attention and concentration.
{% endif %} {% if 16-cancellation-score != undefined %}
Cancellation
{{ 16-cancellation-score }}
This subtest measures rate of test taking, speed of visual-perceptual processing and decision making, visual scanning ability, and visual-perceptual recognition and discrimination.
{% endif %}
{% endif %} {% if 3-fluid-reasoning == true or 4-working-memory == true or 17-complimentary-subtests == true %}
General Abilities
{% endif %} {% if 3-fluid-reasoning == true %}
FLUID REASONING
Subtest
Score
Description
{% if 7-matrix-reasoning-score != undefined %}
Matrix Reasoning
{{ 7-matrix-reasoning-score }}
The subtest is designed to measure fluid intelligence, broad visual intelligence, classification and spatial ability, knowledge of part-whole relationships, and simultaneous processing.
{% endif %} {% if 8-figure-weights-score != undefined %}
Figure Weights
{{ 8-figure-weights-score }}
The subtest measures quantitative fluid reasoning and induction, as well as emphasized inductive or deductive logic.
{% endif %} {% if 9-picture-concepts-score != undefined %}
Picture Concepts
{{ 9-picture-concepts-score }}
The subtest measures fluid and inductive reasoning, visual-perceptual recognition and processing, and conceptual thinking. It also requires visual scanning, working memory, and abstract reasoning.
{% endif %} {% if 10-arithmetic-score != undefined %}
Arithmetic
{{ 10-arithmetic-score }}
The subtest involves mental manipulation, concentration, brief focused attention, working memory, short- and long-term memory, numerical reasoning ability, applied computational ability, and mental alertness. Additionally, it requires sequential processing; fluid, quantitative, and logical reasoning; and quantitative knowledge.
{% endif %}
{% endif %} {% if 4-working-memory == true %}
WORKING MEMORY
Subtest
Score
Description
{% if 11-digit-span-score != undefined %}
Digit Span
{{ 11-digit-span-score }}
Requires cognitive flexibility, mental alertness, brief focused attention, auditory discrimination, and auditory rehearsal. Forward task – measures auditory rehearsal and temporary storage capacity in working memory. Backward task – involves working memory, transformation of information, mental manipulation, and may involve visuospatial imaging. Sequencing task – measures working memory, mental manipulation, and complex sequencing.
{% endif %} {% if 12-picture-span-score != undefined %}
Picture Span
{{ 12-picture-span-score }}
The subtest measures visual working memory and working memory capacity through the use of semantically meaningful stimuli.
{% endif %} {% if 13-letter--number-sequencing-score != undefined %}
Letter- Number Sequencing
{{ 13-letter--number-sequencing-score }}
The subtest involves auditory discrimination, brief focused attention, concentration, registration, and auditory rehearsal. It also measures sequential processing, the ability to compare stimuli based on quantity or alphabetic principles, working memory capacity, and mental manipulation.
{% endif %}
{% endif %} {% if 17-complimentary-subtests == true %}
COMPLIMENTARY SUBTESTS
Subtest
Score
Description
{% if 73-naming-speed-literacy-score != undefined %}
Naming Speed Literacy
{{ 73-naming-speed-literacy-score }}
This subtest specifically measures the automaticity of visual-verbal associations, which should be well developed in school-age children. This subtest was not designed as a measure of intelligence but to enable clinicians to identify difficulties in cognitive processes associated with academic learning.
{% endif %} {% if 74-naming-speed-quality-score != undefined %}
Naming Speed Quality
{{ 74-naming-speed-quality-score }}
The subtest has tasks similar to the experimental literature that show greater sensitivity to mathematics skills and specific learning disorder-mathematics than do the traditional rapid automatized naming tasks that are more closely associated with reading – and writing – related variables.
{% endif %} {% if 77-recognition-symbol-translation-score != undefined %}
Recognition Symbol Translation
{{ 77-recognition-symbol-translation-score }}
This subtest measure verbal-visual associative memory or paired associates learning, storage and retrieval fluency and accuracy, and delayed recognition. It is not a measure of intelligence but a measure of cognitive process related to learning.
{% endif %} {% if 75-immediate-symbol-translation-score != undefined %}
Immediate Symbol Translation
{{ 75-immediate-symbol-translation-score }}
This subtest has tasks similar to Immediate Symbol Translation measure verbal-visual associative memory or paired associates learning, storage, and retrieval fluency and accuracy, and immediate recall. This subtest was not designed as a measure of intelligence but as a measure of cognitive processes that may be interfering with academic learning.
{% endif %} {% if 76-delayed-symbol-translation-score != undefined %}
Delayed Symbol Translation
{{ 76-delayed-symbol-translation-score }}
This subtest is a cued memory paradigm. Tasks similar to Delayed Symbol Translation measure verbal-visual associative memory or paired associates learning, storage and retrieval fluency and accuracy, and delayed recall. This subtest is not designed as a measure of intelligence but as a measure of cognitive process related to learning difficulties.
{% endif %}
{% endif %} {% if 1-wisc-v-summary-abilities != undefined or 1-wisc-v-summary-challenges != undefined %}
SUMMARY

Overall, {{ di-name }}'s performance on the WISC-V provided a snapshot into {% if di-gender == 'Boy' %} his {% else %} her {% endif %} various cognitive abilities and strengths. {% if di-gender == 'Boy' %} He {% else %} She {% endif %} demonstrated well-developed {{ 1-wisc-v-summary-abilities }} abilities. However, {% if di-gender == 'Boy' %} he {% else %} she {% endif %} also evidenced relative challenges with {{ 1-wisc-v-summary-challenges }}. These challenges should continue to be monitored and evaluated so as to help {% if di-gender == 'Boy' %} him {% else %} her {% endif %} continue to perform at {% if di-gender == 'Boy' %} his {% else %} her {% endif %} best.

{% endif %}
{% endif %} {% if CTONI-2 == true %}

Intelligence

The Comprehensive Test of Nonverbal Intelligence 2 

 CTONI-2

CTONI-2 is a norm-referenced assessment that uses nonverbal formats to measure general intelligence of children and adults (6-89 years) whose performance on traditional tests might be adversely affected by subtle or overt impairments involving language or motor abilities.

The CTONI-2 measures analogical reasoning, categorical classification, and sequential reasoning, using six subtests in two different contexts: Pictures of familiar objects (e.g., people, toys, animals) and geometric designs (unfamiliar sketches and drawings).

{% if 151-principals == true %}
Principals

The CTONI-2 has two principal uses. The first use is to estimate the intelligence of people for whom traditional ability tests might be inappropriate. For such persons, the heavy language content or the complicated motor response demands of most mental ability tests can result in a serious underestimation of the intelligence. This often leads to misidentifications, faulty diagnoses, erroneous placements, low expectations, and other undesirable consequences. Use of the CTONI-2 will avoid many of the hazards that are frequently encountered when testing people who have a variety of disabilities (e.g., traumatic brain injury, post-stroke syndrome, deafness, aphasia, autism, or other language disorders) or come from cultural, linguistic, educational, or socioeconomic backgrounds that might negatively influence their performance on ability tests. The CTONI-2’s second use is to provide researchers with a tool that they can use to study the nature of intelligence, the interaction of verbal and nonverbal abilities, and the role of nonverbal formats in assessing thinking and academic subject matters.

Subtest
Score
Description
{% if 172-pictorial-analogies-score != undefined %}
Pictorial Analogies
{{ 172-pictorial-analogies-score }}
Measures the ability to recognize the relationship of two objects to each other and to find the same relationship between two different objects.
{% endif %} {% if 173-geometric-analogies-score != undefined %}
Geometric Analogies
{{ 173-geometric-analogies-score }}
Measures the ability to recognize the relationship of two geometric designs to each other and to find the same relationship between two different geometric designs.
{% endif %} {% if 174-pictorial-categories-score != undefined %}
Pictorial Categories
{{ 174-pictorial-categories-score }}
Measures the ability to select from a set of different pictures the one that is the most similar to two other related pictures.
{% endif %} {% if 175-geometric-categories-score != undefined %}
Geometric Categories
{{ 175-geometric-categories-score }}
Measures the ability to select from a set of different pictures the one that is the most similar to two other related pictures.
{% endif %} {% if 176-pictorial-sequences-score != undefined %}
Pictorial Sequences
{{ 176-pictorial-sequences-score }}
Measures the ability to select from a set of pictures the one that completes a sequence of actions shown in three pictures.
{% endif %} {% if 177-geometric-sequences-score != undefined %}
Geometric Sequences
{{ 177-geometric-sequences-score }}
Measures the ability to select from a set of geometric designs the one that completes a sequence of action shown in three designs.
{% endif %}
{% endif %} {% if 152-composites == true %}
Composites

In addition to the subtests, the CTONI-2 also has three composites. Two composites represent the contexts used to measure the abilities (Pictorial Scale and Geometric Scale). The third composite, the Full Scale, is the overall ability score on the test. All three composites measure general intelligence.

Subtest
Score
Description
{% if 178-pictorial-scale-score != undefined %}
Pictorial Scale
{{ 178-pictorial-scale-score }}
This composite is formed by combining the scaled scores of the three subtests that use pictures of objects (i.e., Pictorial Analogies, Pictorial Categories, and Pictorial Sequences.
{% endif %} {% if 179-geometric-scale-score != undefined %}
Geometric Scale
{{ 179-geometric-scale-score }}
This composite is formed by combining the scaled scores of the three subtests that use images involving points, lines, angles, surfaces, and solids (i.e., Geometric Analogies, Geometric Categories, and Geometric Sequences).
{% endif %} {% if 180-full-scale-score != undefined %}
Full Scale
{{ 180-full-scale-score }}
The index for the Full Scales is the best measure of intelligence because it is the most reliable score on the CTONI-2.
{% endif %}

{% endif %} {% if DAS-II == true %}

Intelligence

Differential Ability Scales 2 

 DAS-II

DAS-II is a comprehensive and flexible instrument for assessing the cognitive abilities that are important to the learning processes of children and adolescents from ages 2 years 6 months through 17 years 11 months (2:6-17:11).

The core subtests yield a composite score that is focused on reasoning and conceptual abilities, called the General Conceptual Ability (GCA) score. A set of optional diagnostic subtests provide additional information on specific abilities.

In addition to contributing to the GCA, the core subtests produce two or three lower-level composite or cluster scores. For children ages 2:6-3:5, the core subtests yield cluster scores measuring Verbal Ability and Nonverbal Ability. For children ages 3:6-17:11, the core subtests yield three cluster scores measuring Verbal Ability, Nonverbal Reasoning Ability, and Spatial Ability.

{% if 10-das-ii-gca-range != undefined or 10-das-ii-gca-score != undefined or 10-das-ii-gca-percentile != undefined or 10-das-ii-snc-range != undefined or 10-das-ii-snc-score != undefined or 10-das-ii-snc-percentile != undefined %}
General Conceptual Ability

{{ di-name }}'s GCA score on the DAS-II places {% if di-gender == 'Boy' %} him{% else %} her{% endif %} in the {{ 10-das-II-gca-range }} range (DAS-II GCA score of {{ 10-das-II-gca-score }}, {{ 10-das-II-gca-percentile }} percentile) while {% if di-gender == 'Boy' %} his{% else %} her{% endif %} (Special Nonverbal Composite SNC score placed in the {{ 10-das-II-snc-range }} range (DAS-II SNC score of {{ 10-das-II-snc-score }}, {{ 10-das-II-snc-percentile }} percentile).

{% endif %}

{% endif %} {% if WASI-II == true %}

Intelligence

Wechsler Abbreviated Scale of Intelligence II 

 WASI-II

The Wechsler Abbreviated Scale of Intelligence Second Edition is an abbreviated test of intellectual abilities which is administered to adolescents and adults 16-90 years of age. The WASI-II estimates intellectual functioning in two areas (i.e., Verbal Comprehension and Perceptual Reasoning) and generates two composite scores that estimate general intellectual ability.

Full Scale IQ-2

The Full Scale IQ-2 is a composite score that represents estimated intellectual functioning and is calculated from 2 of the subtests within the Verbal Comprehension and Perceptual Reasoning indices.

Full Scale IQ-4

The Full Scale IQ-4 is a composite score that represents estimated intellectual functioning and is calculated from the 4 subtests within the Verbal Comprehension and Perceptual Reasoning indices.

{% if 3-if-fsiq-is-meaningful == true %}

Overall, (client) demonstrated a consistent performance on the WASI-II and received a Full-Scale IQ (FSIQ) score of {{ 3-wasi-ii-fsiq-score }} ({{ 3-wasi-ii-fsiq-percentile }} percentile), which falls within in the {{ 3-wasi-ii-fsiq-rank }} range when compared to {% if di-gender == 'Boy' %} his {% else %} her {% endif %} same-aged peers.

{% else %}

Overall, {{ di-name }} demonstrated an inconsistent performance on the WASI-II. As a result, {% if di-gender == 'Boy' %} his {% else %} her {% endif %} Full-Scale score cannot be interpreted meaningfully due to the significant discrepancies between the five Composite areas that constitute {% if di-gender == 'Boy' %} his {% else %} her {% endif %} Full-Scale score (FSIQ). Therefore, in order to better understand {% if di-gender == 'Boy' %} his {% else %} her {% endif %} cognitive strengths and weaknesses, a more in-depth look at all of {{ di-name }}'s individual subtest scores is warranted.

{% endif %}
{% if 57-verbal-comprehension == true %}
Verbal Comprehension

{{ di-name }} demonstrated a relatively {% if 57-wasi-ii-verbal-comprehension-consistent == true %} consistent {% endif %} {% if 57-wasi-ii-verbal-comprehension-inconsistent == true %} inconsistent {% endif %} {% if 57-wasi-ii-verbal-comprehension-freehand-performance != undefined %} {{ 57-wasi-ii-verbal-comprehension-freehand-performance }} {% endif %} performance on the subtests within the Verbal Comprehension Index (VCI). Specifically, {% if di-gender == 'Boy' %} his {% else %} her {% endif %} received a VCI Composite score of {{ 57-wasi-ii-verbal-comprehension-composite-score }} ({{ 57-wasi-ii-verbal-comprehension-composite-percentile }} percentile), which falls within in the {{ 57-wasi-ii-verbal-comprehension-composite-range }} range of functioning compared to other adults {% if di-gender == 'Boy' %} his {% else %} her {% endif %} same-aged peers. The VCI measured {{ di-name }}'s verbal reasoning, knowledge and conceptualization.

Subtest
Score
Description
{% if 246-similarities-score != undefined %}
Similarities
{{ 246-similarities-score }}
The subtest is designed to measure verbal concept formation and abstract reasoning. It also involves crystallized intelligence, word knowledge, cognitive flexibility, auditory comprehension, long-term memory, associative and categorical thinking, distinction between nonessential and essential features, and verbal expression.
{% endif %} {% if 247-vocabulary-score != undefined %}
Vocabulary
{{ 247-vocabulary-score }}
The subtest is designed to measure word knowledge and verbal concept formation. It also measures crystallized intelligence, fund of knowledge, learning ability, verbal expression, long-term memory, and degree of vocabulary development.
{% endif %}
{% endif %} {% if 58-perceptual-reasoning == true %}
Perceptual Reasoning

{{ di-name }} demonstrated a relatively {% if 58-wasi-ii-perceptual-reasoning-consistent == true %} consistent {% endif %} {% if 58-wasi-ii-perceptual-reasoning-inconsistent == true %} inconsistent {% endif %} {% if 58-wasi-ii-perceptual-reasoning-freehand-performance != undefined %} {{ 58-wasi-ii-perceptual-reasoning-freehand-performance }} {% endif %} performance on the subtests within the Fluid Reasoning Index (FRI). This index emphasizes visual-perceptual and visual-spatial reasoning, as well as conceptual reasoning and construction abilities requiring visual-perceptual integration. Specifically, {% if di-gender == 'Boy' %} he {% else %} she {% endif %} received a FRI Composite score of {{ 58-wasi-ii-perceptual-reasoning-composite-score }} ({{ 58-wasi-ii-perceptual-reasoning-composite-percentile }} percentile), which falls within in the {{ 58-wasi-ii-perceptual-reasoning-composite-range }} range of functioning.

It also involved nonverbal concept formation and reasoning, broad visual intelligence, visual perception and organization, simultaneous processing, visual-motor coordination, learning, and the ability to separate figure-ground in visual stimuli.
{% endif %} {% if 249-matrix-reasoning-score != undefined %}
Matrix Reasoning
{{ 249-matrix-reasoning-score }}
The subtest is designed to measure fluid intelligence, broad visual intelligence, classification and spatial ability, knowledge of part-whole relationships, and simultaneous processing.
{% endif %}
{% endif %} {% if 3-wasi-ii-summary-abilities != undefined or 3-wasi-ii-summary-challenges != undefined %}
SUMMARY

Overall, {{ di-name }}'s performance on the WASI-II provided a snapshot into {% if di-gender == 'Boy' %} his {% else %} her {% endif %} various cognitive abilities and strengths. {% if di-gender == 'Boy' %} He {% else %} She {% endif %} demonstrated well-developed {{ 3-wasi-ii-summary-abilities }} abilities. {% endif %} {% if WAIS-IV == true %}

Intelligence

The Wechsler Adult Intelligence Scale IV 

 WAIS-IV

WAIS-IV is a test of intellectual abilities, which assesses both cognitive strengths and weaknesses in adolescents and adults 16-90 years of age.

Full Scale IQ

The Full Scale IQ is a composite score that represents general intellectual functioning and is calculated from all of the subtests within the four main indices: Verbal Comprehension, Perceptual Reasoning, Working Memory and Processing Speed.

{% if 5-if-fsiq-is-meaningful == true %}

Overall, (client) demonstrated a consistent performance on the WAIS-IV and received a Full-Scale IQ (FSIQ) score of {{ 5-wais-iv-fsiq-score }} ({{ 5-wais-iv-fsiq-percentile }} percentile), which falls within in the {{ 5-wais-iv-fsiq-rank }} range when compared to {% if di-gender == 'Boy' %} his {% else %} her {% endif %} same-aged peers.

{% else %}

Overall, {{ di-name }} demonstrated an inconsistent performance on the WAIS-IV. As a result, {% if di-gender == 'Boy' %} his {% else %} her {% endif %} Full-Scale score cannot be interpreted meaningfully due to the significant discrepancies between the five Composite areas that constitute {% if di-gender == 'Boy' %} his {% else %} her {% endif %} Full-Scale score (FSIQ). Therefore, in order to better understand {% if di-gender == 'Boy' %} his {% else %} her {% endif %} cognitive strengths and weaknesses, a more in-depth look at all of {{ di-name }}'s individual subtest scores is warranted.

{% endif %}
GENERAL ABILITY INDEX

The General Ability Index (GIA) is a composite score that provides an estimate of general intellectual ability, with reduced emphasis on working memory and processing speed relative to the FSIQ. {{ di-name }}'s GAI places {% if di-gender == 'Boy' %} him{% else %} her{% endif %} in the {{ 6-wais-iv-gai-range }} range and at the {{ 6-wais-iv-gai-percentile }} percentile.

{% if 106-verbal-comprehension == true %}
Verbal Comprehension

{{ di-name }} demonstrated a relatively {% if 106-wais-iv-verbal-comprehension-consistent == true %} consistent {% endif %} {% if 106-wais-iv-verbal-comprehension-inconsistent == true %} inconsistent {% endif %} {% if 106-wais-iv-verbal-comprehension-freehand-performance != undefined %} {{ 106-wais-iv-verbal-comprehension-freehand-performance }} {% endif %} performance on the subtests within the Verbal Comprehension Index (VCI). Specifically, {% if di-gender == 'Boy' %} he {% else %} she {% endif %} received a VCI Composite score of {{ 106-wais-iv-verbal-comprehension-composite-score }} ({{ 106-wais-iv-verbal-comprehension-composite-percentile }} percentile), which falls within in the {{ 106-wais-iv-verbal-comprehension-composite-range }} range of functioning compared to other adults {% if di-gender == 'Boy' %} his {% else %} her {% endif %} same-aged peers. The VCI measured {{ di-name }}'s verbal reasoning, knowledge and conceptualization.

Specifically, {% if di-gender == 'Boy' %} he {% else %} she {% endif %} received a FRI Composite score of {{ 107-wais-iv-perceptual-reasoning-composite-score }} ({{ 107-wais-iv-perceptual-reasoning-composite-percentile }} percentile), which falls within in the {{ 107-wais-iv-perceptual-reasoning-composite-range }} range of functioning.

Subtest

It also involved nonverbal concept formation and reasoning, broad visual intelligence, visual perception and organization, simultaneous processing, visual-motor coordination, learning, and the ability to separate figure-ground in visual stimuli.

{% endif %} {% if 108-working-memory == true %}
Working Memory

{{ di-name }} demonstrated a relatively {% if 108-wais-iv-working-memory-consistent == true %} consistent {% endif %} {% if 108-wais-iv-working-memory-inconsistent == true %} inconsistent {% endif %} {% if 108-wais-iv-working-memory-freehand-performance != undefined %} {{ 108-wais-iv-working-memory-freehand-performance }} {% endif %} performance on the subtests within the Working Memory Index (WMI). This index measures attention, concentration, and working memory for both verbal and visual material. Specifically, {% if di-gender == 'Boy' %} he {% else %} she {% endif %} received a WMI Composite score of {{ 108-wais-iv-working-memory-composite-score }} ({{ 108-wais-iv-working-memory-composite-percentile }} percentile), which falls within in the {{ 108-wais-iv-working-memory-composite-range }} range of functioning compared to {% if di-gender == 'Boy' %} his {% else %} her {% endif %} peers.

Subtest
Score
Description
{% if 466-digit-span-score != undefined %}
Digit Span
{{ 466-digit-span-score }}
The subtest requires cognitive flexibility, mental alertness, brief focused attention, auditory discrimination, and auditory rehearsal.
  • Forward task – measures auditory rehearsal and temporary storage capacity in working memory.
  • Backward task – involves working memory, transformation of information, mental manipulation, and may involve visuospatial imaging.
  • Sequencing task – measures working memory, mental manipulation, and complex sequencing.
{% endif %} {% if 467-arithmetic-score != undefined %}
Arithmetic
{{ 467-arithmetic-score }}
The subtest involves mental manipulation, concentration, brief focused attention, working memory, short- and long-term memory, numerical reasoning ability, applied computational ability, and mental alertness. Additionally, it requires sequential processing; fluid, quantitative, and logical reasoning; and quantitative knowledge.
{% endif %} {% if 468-letter--number-sequencing-score != undefined %}
Letter-Number Sequencing
{{ 468-letter--number-sequencing-score }}
The subtest involves auditory discrimination, brief focused attention, concentration, registration, and auditory rehearsal. It also measures sequential processing, the ability to compare stimuli based on quantity or alphabetic principles, working memory capacity, and mental manipulation.
{% endif %}
{% endif %} {% if 109-processing-speed == true %}

{{ di-name }} demonstrated a relatively {% if 109-wais-iv-processing-speed-consistent == true %} consistent {% endif %} {% if 109-wais-iv-processing-speed-inconsistent == true %} inconsistent {% endif %} {% if 109-wais-iv-processing-speed-freehand-performance != undefined %} {{ 109-wais-iv-processing-speed-freehand-performance }} {% endif %} performance on the subtests within the Working Memory Index (WMI). The Processing Speed domain measured {{ di-name }}'s speed of mental and graphomotor processing, as well as their ability to efficiently scan and process visual information. Specifically, {% if di-gender == 'Boy' %} he {% else %} she {% endif %} received a PSI Composite score of {{ 109-wais-iv-processing-speed-composite-score }} ({{ 109-wais-iv-processing-speed-composite-percentile }} percentile), which falls within in the {{ 109-wais-iv-processing-speed-composite-range }} range of functioning compared to {% if di-gender == 'Boy' %} his {% else %} her {% endif %} peers.

SUMMARY

{% endif %} {% if WJ-IV-COG == true %}

Intelligence

Woodcock-Johnson IV – Tests of Cognitive Abilities 

 WJ-IV COG

WJ-IV COG is a test of intellectual abilities, which assesses both strengths and weaknesses in children and adults ages 2-90 years of age.

General Intellectual Ability (GIA)

The GIA is a composite score that represents an estimate of general intellectual functioning and is calculated from a combination of subtests that form various clusters: Comprehension Knowledge, Short Term Working Memory, Cognitive Processing Speed, Auditory Processing, Long Term Processing and Visual Processing.

{% if 7-if-gia-is-meaningful == true %}

Overall, (client) demonstrated a consistent performance on the WJ-IV and received a General Intellectual Ability (GIA) score of {{ 7-wj-iv-cog-fsiq-score }} ({{ 7-wj-iv-cog-fsiq-percentile }} percentile), which falls within in the {{ 7-wj-iv-cog-fsiq-rank }} range when compared to {% if di-gender == 'Boy' %} his {% else %} her {% endif %} same-aged peers.

{% else %}

Overall, {{ di-name }} demonstrated an inconsistent performance on the WJ-IV. As a result, {% if di-gender == 'Boy' %} his {% else %} her {% endif %} GIA score cannot be interpreted meaningfully due to the significant discrepancies between the seven clusters. Therefore, in order to better understand {% if di-gender == 'Boy' %} his {% else %} her {% endif %} cognitive strengths and weaknesses, a more in-depth look at all of {{ di-name }}'s individual subtest scores is warranted.

{% endif %}
{% if 134-comprehension-knowledge-gc == true %}
Comprehension-Knowledge (Gc)

Gc is a composite score that provides a estimate of crystalized intelligence or verbal ability, which is defined as a store of acquired knowledge that reflects the breadth and depth of knowledge of a culture. Comprehension-Knowledge (Gc) is composed of two tests Oral Vocabulary and General Information.

Comprehension-Knowledge (Gc)

{{ di-name }} demonstrated a relatively {% if 134-wj-iv-cog-comprehension-knowledge-gc-consistent == true %} consistent {% endif %} {% if 134-wj-iv-cog-comprehension-knowledge-gc-inconsistent == true %} inconsistent {% endif %} {% if 134-wj-iv-cog-comprehension-knowledge-gc-freehand-performance != undefined %} {{ 134-wj-iv-cog-comprehension-knowledge-gc-freehand-performance }} {% endif %} performance on the subtests within the Comprehension-Knowledge (Gc) cluster. Specifically, {% if di-gender == 'Boy' %} he {% else %} she {% endif %} received a Gc score of {{ 134-wj-iv-cog-comprehension-knowledge-gc-composite-score }} ({{ 134-wj-iv-cog-comprehension-knowledge-gc-composite-percentile }} percentile), which falls within in the {{ 134-wj-iv-cog-comprehension-knowledge-gc-composite-range }} range of functioning compared to other individuals {% if di-gender == 'Boy' %} his {% else %} her {% endif %} same-aged peers. The Gc cluster measured {{ di-name }}'s breadth and depth of knowledge and skills, including verbal communication and reasoning ability.

Subtest
Score
Description
{% if 593-vocabulary-score != undefined %}
Vocabulary
{{ 593-vocabulary-score }}
Oral Vocabulary includes two subtests, Synonyms and Antonyms. Each subtest is designed to measure an aspect of vocabulary knowledge of spoken English to provide an estimate of an individual’s acquired knowledge.
{% endif %} {% if 594-general-information-score != undefined %}
General Information
{{ 594-general-information-score }}
General Information includes two subtests, Where and What. The subtests are designed to measure an individual’s depth of knowledge and general information.
{% endif %}
{% endif %} {% if 135-fluid-reasoning-gf == true %}
Fluid Reasoning (Gf)

Gf is a composite score that provides an estimate of ability to reason, form concepts, and solve problems using unfamiliar information or novel procedures. Fluid reason requires deliberate and flexible control of attention to solve on the spot problems.

Fluid Reasoning (Gf)

{{ di-name }} demonstrated a relatively {% if 135-wj-iv-cog-fluid-reasoning-gf-consistent == true %} consistent {% endif %} {% if 135-wj-iv-cog-fluid-reasoning-gf-inconsistent == true %} inconsistent {% endif %} {% if 135-wj-iv-cog-fluid-reasoning-gf-freehand-performance != undefined %} {{ 135-wj-iv-cog-fluid-reasoning-gf-freehand-performance }} {% endif %} performance on the subtests within the Fluid Reasoning (Gf) cluster. The Gf cluster measured {{ di-name }}'s ability to reason, form concepts and solve problems using unfamiliar information or novel procedures.

Subtest
Score
Description

{{ 595-number-series-score }}
The subtest is designed to measure quantitative reasoning and indicative reasoning, narrow abilities of fluid reasoning.
{% endif %} {% if 596-concept-formation-score != undefined %}
Concept Formation
{{ 596-concept-formation-score }}
The subtest is designed to measure concept formation, categorical reasoning and mental flexibility.
{% endif %} {% if 597-analysis-synthesis-score != undefined %}

{{ 597-analysis-synthesis-score }}

Gwm is a composite score that provides an estimate of ability to apprehend and hold information in immediate awareness and then use or manipulate it to carry out a goal.

The Gwm cluster measured {{ di-name}}'s ability to apprehend and hold information in immediate awareness and then use or manipulate it.

Intelligence

Wechsler Preschool & Primary Scale of Intelligence IV 

 WPPSI-IV

WPPSI-IV is a test of intellectual abilities, which assesses both cognitive strengths and weaknesses in infants and children aged 2 years 6 months through 7 years 7 months (2:6-7:7).

Full Scale IQ

The Full Scale IQ is a composite score that represents general intellectual functioning and is calculated from all of the subtests within the main indices.

{% if 9-if-fsiq-is-meaningful == true %}

Overall, (client) demonstrated a consistent performance on the WPPSI-IV and received a Full-Scale IQ (FSIQ) score of {{ 9-wppsi-iv-fsiq-score }} ({{ 9-wppsi-iv-fsiq-percentile }} percentile), which falls within in the {{ 9-wppsi-iv-fsiq-rank }} range when compared to {% if di-gender == 'Boy' %} his {% else %} her {% endif %} same-aged peers.

{% else %}

Overall, {{ di-name }} demonstrated an inconsistent performance on the WPPSI-IV. As a result, {% if di-gender == 'Boy' %} his {% else %} her {% endif %} Full-Scale score cannot be interpreted meaningfully due to the significant discrepancies between the five Composite areas that constitute {% if di-gender == 'Boy' %} his {% else %} her {% endif %} Full-Scale score (FSIQ). Therefore, in order to better understand {% if di-gender == 'Boy' %} his {% else %} her {% endif %} cognitive strengths and weaknesses, a more in-depth look at all of {{ di-name }}'s individual subtest scores is warranted.

{% endif %}
GENERAL ABILITY INDEX

The General Ability Index is a composite score that provides an estimate of general intellectual ability, with reduced emphasis on working memory and processing speed relative to the FSIQ.

{% if 153-verbal-comprehension == true %}
Verbal Comprehension
Subtest
Score
Description
{% if 647-similarities-score != undefined %}
Similarities
{{ 647-similarities-score }}
The subtest is designed to measure verbal concept formation and abstract reasoning. It also involves crystallized intelligence, auditory comprehension, memory, associative and categorical thinking, distinction between nonessential and essential features, and verbal expression.
{% endif %} {% if 648-vocabulary-score != undefined %}
Vocabulary
{{ 648-vocabulary-score }}
The subtest is designed to measure word knowledge and verbal concept formation. It also measures crystallized intelligence, fund of knowledge, learning ability, verbal expression, long-term memory, and degree of vocabulary development.
{% endif %} {% if 649-information-score != undefined %}
Information
{{ 649-information-score }}
This subtest is designed to measure a child’s ability to acquire, retain, and retrieve general factual knowledge. It involves crystallized intelligence, long-term memory, and the ability to retain and retrieve knowledge from the environment and/or school.
{% endif %} {% if 650-comprehension-score != undefined %}
Comprehension
{{ 650-comprehension-score }}
It is designed to measure verbal reasoning and conceptualization, verbal comprehension and expression, the ability to evaluate and use past experience, and the ability to demonstrate practical knowledge and judgement.
