The Hypomania scale is intended to measure milder degrees of excitement, characterized by an elated but unstable mood, psychomotor excitement.
{% endif %} {% if 548-social-introversion-si-score != undefined %}
Social Introversion (Si)
{{ 548-social-introversion-si-score }}
The Social Introversion scale measures the social introversion and extroversion of a person.
{% endif %}
{% endif %} {% if 127-validity-scales == true %}
Validity Scales

The Minnesota Multiphasic Personality Inventory-A (MMPI-A) contains eight validity scales used to describe the extent of the individual’s cooperation with the assessment. It can indicate whether the individual wanted to call attention to his or her symptoms or, conversely, if he or she was inclined to deny problems.

Scale
Score
Description
{% if 549-cns-score != undefined %}
CNS
{{ 549-cns-score }}
“Cannot Say”. Questions not answered.
{% endif %} {% if 550-vrin-score != undefined %}
VRIN
{{ 550-vrin-score }}
Variable Response Inconsistency. Answering similar/opposite question pairs inconsistently.
{% endif %} {% if 551-trin-score != undefined %}
TRIN
{{ 551-trin-score }}
True Response Inconsistency. Answering questions all true/all false.
{% endif %} {% if 552-f-score != undefined %}
F
{{ 552-f-score }}
The F scale is intended to detect unusual or atypical ways of answering the test items.
{% endif %} {% if 553-f1-score != undefined %}
F1
{{ 553-f1-score }}
The F1 scale is intended to detect unusual or atypical ways of answering questions in the first 350 items.
{% endif %} {% if 554-f2-score != undefined %}
F2
{{ 554-f2-score }}
The F2 scale is intended to detect unusual or atypical ways of answering questions after the first 240 items.
{% endif %} {% if 555-l-score != undefined %}
L
{{ 555-l-score }}
The Lie scale is intended to identify individuals who are deliberately trying to avoid answering the MMPI honestly and in a frank manner.
{% endif %} {% if 556-k-score != undefined %}
K
{{ 556-k-score }}
Defensiveness. Denial/Evasiveness.
{% endif %}
{% endif %}
{% endif %} {% if Rorschach == true %}

Social-Emotional

Rorschach

Rorschach is a projective free response measure that prompts the examinee to provide responses to a series of inkblots. Responses are carefully analyzed according to the Comprehensive System. The test provides a measure of personality functioning across various domains including capacity for control, tolerance for stress, affect, self perception, interpersonal perception, information processing, cognitive mediation, and ideation.

{% endif %} {% if TSCC == true %}

Social-Emotional

Trauma Symptom Checklist for Children 

 TSCC

TSCC (Trauma Symptom Checklist for Children) is a self-report measure of posttraumatic distress and related psychological symptomatology. It is intended for use in the evaluation of children who have experienced traumatic events, including childhood physical and sexual abuse, victimization by peers (e.g., physical or sexual assault), major losses, the witnessing of violence done to others, and natural disasters.

{% if 142-validity-scale == true %}
Validity Scale

TSCC has two validity scales: one that taps a child’s tendency to deny any symptomatology and one that indexes a tendency to overrespond to symptom items.

  • Underresponse (UND) → The UND scale reflects the extent to which the respondent denied behaviors, thoughts, or feelings that most others would report at some nonzero level.
  • Hyperresponse (HYP) → Is when the child indiscriminately endorses the highest frequency point for many or all symptom items.
Scale
Score
Description
{% if 608-underresponse-und-score != undefined %}
Underresponse (UND)
{{ 608-underresponse-und-score }}
Consists of the number of 0s endorsed for those items least likely to receive a 0 in the normative sample. Reflects a tendency toward denial, a general under-endorsement response set, or a need to appear unusually symptom-free.
{% endif %} {% if 609-hyperresponse-hyp-score != undefined %}
Hyperresponse (HYP)
{{ 609-hyperresponse-hyp-score }}
Consists of the number of 3s marked on diverse items that rarely received a 3 in the normative sample. Indicates a general overresponse to TSCC items, a specific need to appear especially symptomatic, or a state of being overwhelmed by traumatic stress.
{% endif %}
{% endif %} {% if 143-clinical-scale == true %}
Clinical Scale

The clinical scales of the TSCC measure the extent to which the child endorses six different types of potentially trauma-related symptoms. Five of the six scales (all but PTS) are nonoverlapping at the item level. Two of these clinical scales (DIS and SC) also contain scorable subscales, based upon principle components analyses and scale content.

  • Anxiety (ANX) → Scores on the Anxiety (ANX) scale reflect the extent to which the child is experiencing generalized anxiety, hyperarousal, and worry, as well as specific fears of men or women, of the dark, and of being killed. Also tapped by this scale are episodes of free-floating anxiety and fears of impending danger.
  • Depression (DEP) → The Depression (DEP) scale taps feelings of sadness, unhappiness, and loneliness; episodes of tearfulness; and depressive cognitions such as guilt and self-denigration.
  • Anger (ANG) → Scores on the Anger (ANG) scale indicate the extent of angry thoughts, feelings, and behaviors reported by the child.
  • Posttraumatic Stress → The Posttraumatic Stress (PTS) scale consists of items reflecting classic posttraumatic symptoms.
  • Dissociation (DIS) → The Dissociation (DIS) scale measures the extent to which the child experiences mild-to-moderate dissociative symptomatology.
  • Sexual Concerns (SC) → The Sexual Concerns (SC) scale measures sexual distress and preoccupation.
Scale
Score
Description
{% if 610-anxiety-anx-score != undefined %}
Anxiety (ANX)
{{ 610-anxiety-anx-score }}
Generalized anxiety, hyperarousal, and worry; specific fears (e.g., of men, women, or both; of the dark; of being killed); episodes of free-floating anxiety; and a sense of impending danger.
{% endif %} {% if 611-depression-dep-score != undefined %}
Depression (DEP)
{{ 611-depression-dep-score }}
Feelings of sadness, unhappiness, and loneliness; episodes of tearfulness; depressive cognitions such as guilt and self-denigration; and self-injuriousness and suicidality.
{% endif %} {% if 612-anger-ang-score != undefined %}
Anger (ANG)
{{ 612-anger-ang-score }}
Any thoughts, feelings, and behaviors, including feeling mad, feeling mean, and hating others; having difficulty de-escalating anger; wanting to yell at or hurt people; and arguing and fighting.
{% endif %} {% if 613-posttraumatic-stress-pts-score != undefined %}
Posttraumatic Stress (PTS)
{{ 613-posttraumatic-stress-pts-score }}
Posttraumatic symptoms, including intrusive thoughts, sensations, and memories of painful past events; nightmares; fears; and cognitive avoidance of painful feelings.
{% endif %} {% if 614-dissociation-dis-score != undefined %}
Dissociation (DIS)
{{ 614-dissociation-dis-score }}
Dissociative symptomatology, including derealization; one’s mind going blank; emotional numbing; pretending to be someone else or somewhere else; day-dreaming; memory problems; and dissociative avoidance. Has two subscales: DIS-O (Overt Dissociation) and DIS-F (Fantasy).
{% endif %} {% if 615-sexual-concerns-sc-score != undefined %}
Sexual Concerns (SC)
{{ 615-sexual-concerns-sc-score }}
Sexual thoughts or feelings that are atypical when they occur earlier than expected or with greater than normal frequency; sexual conflicts; negative responses to sexual stimuli; and fear of being sexually exploited. Has two subscales: SC-P (Sexual Preoccupation) and SC-D (Sexual Distress).
{% endif %}
{% endif %}
{% endif %}
{% if di-name != undefined or di-age != undefined or reason-referral-1 != undefined or reason-referral-2 != undefined or reason-referral-3 != undefined or relevant-background-history != undefined or results-current-assessment != undefined or results-current-assessment != undefined or summary-current-situation != undefined %}

Summary of Findings

{% endif %} {% if di-name != undefined or di-age != undefined %}

  • Patient's name: {{ di-name }}

  • Patient's age: {{ di-age }}

{% endif %} {% if reason-referral-1 != undefined or reason-referral-2 != undefined or reason-referral-3 != undefined %}

Reasons for Referral

  • {{ reason-referral-1 }}

  • {{ reason-referral-2 }}

  • {{ reason-referral-3 }}

{% endif %} {% if relevant-background-history != undefined %}

Relevant Background History

{{ relevant-background-history }}

{% endif %} {% if results-current-assessment != undefined %}

Results of Current Assessment

{{ results-current-assessment }}

{% endif %} {% if summary-current-situation != undefined %}

Overall summary of current situation

{{ summary-current-situation }}

{% endif %}
{% if dsm-codes.length > 0 or edu-code-intellectual-disability-id == true or edu-code-hard-of-hearing-hh == true or edu-code-deafness-deaf-hearing-impairment-hi == true or edu-code-speech-or-language-impairment-sli == true or edu-code-visual-impairment-vi == true or edu-code-emotional-disturbance-ed == true or edu-code-orthopedic-impairment-oi == true or edu-code-other-health-impairment-ohi == true or edu-code-established-medical-disability-emd == true or edu-code-specific-learning-disability-sld == true or edu-code-deaf-blindness-db == true or edu-code-multiple-disabilities-md == true or edu-code-autism-aut == true or edu-code-traumatic-brain-injury-tbi == true %}

Diagnostic considerations

{% endif %}
{% if dsm-codes.length > 0 %}

DSM-5 diagnosis (ICD-10)

    {% for code in dsm-codes %}

  • {{ code.codeValue }}

    • {% endfor %}
{% endif %}
{% if edu-code-intellectual-disability-id == true or edu-code-hard-of-hearing-hh == true or edu-code-deafness-deaf-hearing-impairment-hi == true or edu-code-speech-or-language-impairment-sli == true or edu-code-visual-impairment-vi == true or edu-code-emotional-disturbance-ed == true or edu-code-orthopedic-impairment-oi == true or edu-code-other-health-impairment-ohi == true or edu-code-established-medical-disability-emd == true or edu-code-specific-learning-disability-sld == true or edu-code-deaf-blindness-db == true or edu-code-multiple-disabilities-md == true or edu-code-autism-aut == true or edu-code-traumatic-brain-injury-tbi == true %}

Educational classification

{% if edu-code-intellectual-disability-id == true %}

Intellectual Disability (ID) Intellectual Disability means significantly subaverage general intellectual functioning, existing concurrently with deficits in adaptive behavior, and manifested during the developmental period, that adversely affects a child's educational performance. (34 Code of Federal Regulations (CFR), Sec. 300.8(c)(6)).

{% endif %} {% if edu-code-hard-of-hearing-hh == true %}

Hard of hearing (HH) Hard of Hearing means hearing, impairment, whether permanent or fluctuating, that adversely affects a child's educational performance, but that is not included under the definition of deaf in this section.

{% endif %} {% if edu-code-deafness-deaf-hearing-impairment-hi == true %}

Deafness (DEAF)/Hearing impairment (HI) Deafness means a hearing impairment that is so severe that the child is impaired in processing linguistic information through learning, with or without amplification, which adversely affects educational performance. (34 CFR Sec. 300.8(c)(3) Hearing Impairment is a federal category of disability, which includes both hard of hearing and deaf individuals as defined above.

{% endif %} {% if edu-code-speech-or-language-impairment-sli == true %}

Speech or language impairment (SLI) Speech or Language Impairment means a communication disorder such as stuttering, impaired articulation, language impairment, or a voice impairment, that adversely affects a child's educational performance. (34 CFR Sec. 300.8(c)(11)).

{% endif %} {% if edu-code-visual-impairment-vi == true %}

Visual impairment (VI) Visually Impaired, including blindness means impairment in vision that, even with correction, adversely affects a child's educational performance. The term includes both partially seeing and blind children. (34 CFR Sec. 300.8(c)(13)).

{% endif %} {% if edu-code-emotional-disturbance-ed == true %}

Emotional disturbance (ED) Emotional Disturbance means a condition exhibiting one or more of the following characteristics, over a long period of time and to a marked degree, that adversely affects educational performance: (A) An inability to learn which cannot be explained by intellectual, sensory, or health factors; (B) An inability to build or maintain satisfactory interpersonal relationships with peers and teachers; (C) Inappropriate types of behavior or feeling under normal circumstances; (D) A general pervasive mood of unhappiness or depression; or (E) A tendency to develop physical symptoms or fears associated with personal or school problems. The term (ED) includes schizophrenia. The term does not apply to children who are socially maladjusted, unless it is determined that they have an emotional disturbance. (34 CFR Sec. 300.8(c)(4)).

{% endif %} {% if edu-code-orthopedic-impairment-oi == true %}

Orthopedic impairment (OI) Orthopedic Impairment means a severe orthopedic impairment that adversely affects a child's educational performance. The term includes impairments caused by congenital anomaly (e.g., clubfoot, absence of some member, etc.), impairments caused by disease (e.g., poliomyelitis, bone tuberculosis, etc.), and impairments from other causes (e.g., cerebral palsy, amputations, and fractures or burns which cause contractures). (34 CFR Sec. 300.8(b)(6 Sec. 300.8(c)(8)).

{% endif %} {% if edu-code-other-health-impairment-ohi == true %}

Other health impairment (OHI) Other Health Impairment means having limited strength, vitality or alertness, due to chronic or acute health problems such as a heart condition, tuberculosis, rheumatic fever, nephritis, asthma, sickle cell anemia, hemophilia, epilepsy, lead poisoning, leukemia, or diabetes, which adversely affects a child's educational performance. (34 CFR Part 300.8 (c) (9)).

{% endif %} {% if edu-code-established-medical-disability-emd == true %}

Established medical disability (EMD) A disabling medical condition or congenital syndrome that the individualized education program (IEP) team determines has a high predictability of requiring special education and services. (CA Ed Code, Section 56441.11(d)) (Note: This eligibility category is only applicable for children ages 3-5).

{% endif %} {% if edu-code-specific-learning-disability-sld == true %}

Specific learning disability (SLD) Specific Learning Disability means a disorder in one or more of the basic psychological processes involved in understanding or using language, spoken or written, that may manifest itself in an imperfect ability to listen, think, speak, read, write, spell, or to do mathematical calculations, including such conditions as perceptual disabilities, brain injury, minimal brain dysfunction, dyslexia, and developmental aphasia. The term does not include learning problems that are primarily the result of visual, hearing, or motor handicaps, of mental retardation, of emotional disturbance or of environmental, cultural, or economic disadvantage. (34 CFR Sec. 300.8(c)(10)).

{% endif %} {% if edu-code-deaf-blindness-db == true %}

Deaf-blindness (DB) Deaf-Blindness means concomitant hearing and visual impairments, the combination of which causes such severe communication and other developmental and educational needs that they cannot be accommodated in special education programs solely for children with deafness or children with blindness. (34 CFR Sec. 300.8(c)(2)).

{% endif %} {% if edu-code-multiple-disabilities-md == true %}

Multiple disabilities (MD) Multiple Disabilities means concomitant impairments (such as mental retardation-blindness, mental retardation-orthopedic impairment, etc.,) the combination of which causes such severe educational needs that they cannot be accommodated in special education programs solely for one of the impairments. The term does not include deaf-blind children. (34 CFR Sec. 300.8(c)(7)).

{% endif %} {% if edu-code-autism-aut == true %}

Autism (AUT) Autism means a developmental disability significantly affecting verbal and non-verbal communication and social interaction, generally evident before age three, which adversely affects educational performance. Other characteristics often associated with autism include, engagement in repetitive activities and stereotyped movements, resistance to environmental change or change in daily routines, and unusual responses to sensory experiences. The term does not does not apply if a child's educational performance is adversely affected primarily because the child has an emotional disturbance. A child who manifests characteristics of autism after age three, that child could be diagnosed as having autism if the criteria in the above paragraph are satisfied. (34 CFR Sec. 300.8(c)(1)).

{% endif %} {% if edu-code-traumatic-brain-injury-tbi == true %}

Traumatic brain injury (TBI) Traumatic Brain Injury means an acquired injury to the brain caused by an external physical force, resulting in total or partial functional disability or psychosocial impairment, which adversely affects educational performance. The term applies to both open or closed head injuries resulting in impairments in one or more areas, such as cognition; language; memory; attention; reasoning; abstract thinking; judgment; problem-solving; sensory, perceptual and motor abilities; psychosocial behavior; physical functions; information processing; and speech. The term does not include brain injuries that are congenital or degenerative, nor brain injuries induced by birth trauma. (34 CFR Sec. 300.8(c)(12)).

{% endif %}
{% endif %}
{% if recommendation-adhd == true or recommendation-autism == true or recommendation-dementia == true or recommendation-dysthymia == true or recommendation-learning-disability-mathematics == true or recommendation-learning-disability-reading == true or recommendation-neurocognitive-disorder == true %}

Recommendations

Based on the current testing results, recommendations to support {{ di-name }}’s needs and strengths are as follows:

{% endif %} {% if recommendation-adhd == true %}

ADHD

    {% if adhd1-recommendation == true %}
  • Similarly, {{ di-name }} would greatly benefit from continuing to learn and utilizing organizational techniques (i.e., making lists, brainstorming verbally, breaking down large tasks into smaller components) to help {{ di-name }} better manage {{ di-name }}'s work-related tasks.
    • {% endif %} {% if adhd2-recommendation == true %}
  • {{ di-name }} may benefit from seeking out and utilizing individual therapeutic supports to help develop effective coping strategies to manage {{ di-name }} symptoms of anxiety and inattention, as well as build {{ di-name }}'s self-esteem.
    • {% endif %} {% if adhd3-recommendation == true %}
  • {{ di-name }} may also benefit from participating in Neurofeedback to help {{ di-name }} better regulate {{ di-name }}'s symptoms of anxiety, agitation, and inattention. Neurofeedback is considered a natural treatment for improving attention and self-regulation for individuals who want to take a medication free approach to treatment or to enhance the effects of other treatments they are already receiving. With neurofeedback we are enhancing awareness of internal states by allowing the brain to witness its own EEG activity. The goal is to allow the nervous system to calm down and reset itself onto a better path. It also addresses and better regulates symptoms of inattention and anxiety.
    • {% endif %} {% if adhd4-recommendation == true %}
  • It is recommended that {{ di-name }} receive 50% extended testing time on tests and examinations to help {{ di-name }} illustrate {{ di-name }}'s knowledge base to the best of {{ di-name }}'s ability. Extended time would allow {{ di-name }} to take breaks, check {{ di-name }}'s work, access the full scope of the material presented to {{ di-name }}, and provide {{ di-name }} with the needed time to process the testing material.
    • {% endif %} {% if adhd5-recommendation == true %}
  • {{ di-name }} is encouraged to utilize a schedule/planner daily to help {{ di-name }} keep track of important due dates and appointments.
    • {% endif %} {% if adhd6-recommendation == true %}
  • Utilize a homework routine to help accomplish nightly tasks. Example: Allow at most one hour after school to decompress before starting homework. Utilize an alarm to signal when the hour is up so not to lose track of time. To help stay motivated, reward {{ di-name }} during breaks by watching a preferred, short TV show or spending 15-30 minutes in a preferred activity.
    • {% endif %} {% if adhd7-recommendation == true %}
  • {{ di-name }}'s functional impairments also require that {{ di-name }} be allowed to take examinations in a distraction reduced environment.
    • {% endif %} {% if adhd8-recommendation == true %}
  • Given that {{ di-name }}’s symptoms continue to negatively affect {{ di-name }} performance at work, {{ di-name }} may also benefit from a psychiatric consultation to assess whether medication may be an appropriate intervention at this time.
    • {% endif %} {% if adhd9-recommendation == true %}
  • {{ di-name }} would benefit from a medication consultation to determine if psychiatric medication would be appropriate at this time to help {{ di-name }} better manage {{ di-name }}'s symptoms of inattention, anxiety, and agitation.
    • {% endif %} {% if adhd10-recommendation == true %}
  • {{ di-name }} is encouraged to sit closer to teacher/speaker, also require that {{ di-name }} be allowed to take examinations in a distraction reduced environment to help guard against lapses in {{ di-name }}'s attention and concentration.
    • {% endif %} {% if adhd11-recommendation == true %}
  • In addressing ADHD symptoms in preschool, children with ADHD commonly have a great need to touch and move. Giving them something to do with their hands and bodies while sitting in class can help them self-regulate, focus, and function better in the classroom. Teachers are encouraged to experiment with sensory strategies and tools, such as the following:
    • Velcro adhered to the underside of chair or desk — somewhere that {{ di-name }} can easily reach and discretely rub it to keep {{ di-name }}'s hands busy.
    • Seating options such as a rocking chair, exercise ball, or wiggle cushions.
    • Fidget toys (also called sensory toys). Consider looking for resources from companies such as Therapy Shoppe (www.therapyshoppe.com).
    • {% endif %} {% if adhd12-recommendation == true %}
  • {{ di-name }} would also benefit from having an end of the day study hall at school to help complete work.
    • {% endif %}
{% if adhd-recommendations-freehand != undefined %}

Additional ADHD recommendations: {{ adhd-recommendations-freehand }}

{% endif %}
{% endif %} {% if recommendation-autism == true %}

Autism

    {% if autism1-recommendation == true %}
  • {{ di-name }}’s parents should share the results of this evaluation with {% if di-gender == 'Boy' %}his {% else %}her {% endif %}current educators and the following recommendations should be incorporated into {% if di-gender == 'Boy' %}his {% else %}her {% endif %}academic environment.
    • {% endif %} {% if autism2-recommendation == true %}
  • Similarly, {{ di-name }} would also benefit from continuing to engage and participate in speech and language services, occupational therapy, as well social skills classes/groups (both in and out of school). Additionally, {% if di-gender == 'Boy' %}he {% else %}she {% endif %} would also greatly benefit from A.B.A. therapy to help support {% if di-gender == 'Boy' %}his {% else %}her {% endif %}needs outside of the classroom environment.
    • {% endif %} {% if autism3-recommendation == true %}
  • {{ di-name }} would benefit from the following Educational and Academic supports and environments:
      {% if autism3-1-recommendation == true %}
    • {% if di-gender == 'Boy' %}He {% else %}She {% endif %} requires a school that is familiar with and can work with individuals presenting on the Autism Spectrum.
      • {% endif %} {% if autism3-2-recommendation == true %}
    • {{ di-name }}’s diagnoses of Autism Spectrum Disorder and ADHD, Combined Type make it difficult for {% if di-gender == 'Boy' %}him {% else %}her {% endif %} to attend in over-stimulating environments. Therefore, a small class size is recommended to help {{ di-name }} sustain attention, as there will be less extraneous stimuli in the room to distract {% if di-gender == 'Boy' %}him {% else %}her {% endif %}. A classroom that has reduced noise will help {{ di-name }} successfully complete {% if di-gender == 'Boy' %}his {% else %}her {% endif %} tasks. A small class size will also allow {{ di-name }} to receive the attention {% if di-gender == 'Boy' %}he {% else %}she {% endif %} needs to succeed.
      • {% endif %} {% if autism3-3-recommendation == true %}
    • When being asked a question or given a directive, {{ di-name }} will need extra time to process, respond, and act accordingly. It is also imperative to ensure that {{ di-name }} is not perseverating or fixating on preferred items during delivery of directions and commands.
      • {% endif %} {% if autism3-4-recommendation == true %}
    • As academic work increases in difficulty, {{ di-name }} will also benefit from being provided 50% extended time on tests and in-class activities.
      • {% endif %} {% if autism3-5-recommendation == true %}
    • {{ di-name }}’s attention and behavioral difficulties require significant levels of external structure and support. In the class, {{ di-name }} should be provided with predictable routines and clear-cut instructions and expectations. Teachers should speak slowly and repeat instructions as needed. Frequent monitoring should be done to ensure that {% if di-gender == 'Boy' %}he {% else %}she {% endif %} remains on task.
      • {% endif %} {% if autism3-6-recommendation == true %}
    • Multi-step directions/requests and lengthy assignments should be broken down as well.
      • {% endif %} {% if autism3-7-recommendation == true %}
    • {{ di-name }} will often need directions and prompts repeated to {% if di-gender == 'Boy' %}him {% else %}her {% endif %}, as well as having possible answer choices provided to {% if di-gender == 'Boy' %}him {% else %}her {% endif %}.
      • {% endif %} {% if autism3-8-recommendation == true %}
    • {% if di-gender == 'Boy' %}He {% else %}She {% endif %} will also be more successful when verbal directives are paired with visual images to help cue {% if di-gender == 'Boy' %}him {% else %}her {% endif %} to listen and ensure {% if di-gender == 'Boy' %}his {% else %}her {% endif %} attention. When {% if di-gender == 'Boy' %}he {% else %}she {% endif %} is not able to follow directions and comply, it is imperative to make sure {% if di-gender == 'Boy' %}he {% else %}she {% endif %} understands what is being asked of {% if di-gender == 'Boy' %}him {% else %}her {% endif %}.
      • {% endif %} {% if autism3-9-recommendation == true %}
    • Preferential seating near the teacher and in the front of the classroom to help monitor difficulties with attention as well as processing difficulties.
      • {% endif %} {% if autism3-10-recommendation == true %}
    • Teachers and caretakers working with {{ di-name }} should utilize short-term rewards (rather than longer, delayed rewards) as well as frequent, sensory breaks to help {% if di-gender == 'Boy' %}him {% else %}her {% endif %} stay engaged, motivated and on-task with {% if di-gender == 'Boy' %}his {% else %}her {% endif %} activities.
      • {% endif %} {% if autism3-11-recommendation == true %}
    • {{ di-name }} should be provided with frequent breaks during classroom instruction for {% if di-gender == 'Boy' %}him {% else %}her {% endif %} to fully comprehend the information and to increase {% if di-gender == 'Boy' %}his {% else %}her {% endif %} overall compliance.
      • {% endif %} {% if autism3-12-recommendation == true %}
    • Learning activities that increase motivation and arousal will facilitate sustaining attention (e.g., interactive and hands-on), rather than desk work. {{ di-name }} appears to be more of a visual and hands on learner, therefore {% if di-gender == 'Boy' %}he {% else %}she {% endif %} will be more likely to comprehend the information when auditory information is supplemented with visual-based instruction.
      • {% endif %} {% if autism3-13-recommendation == true %}
    • Teachers should assist in helping {{ di-name }} to make and maintain friendships in the classroom. Praise and encouragement should be used to reinforce appropriate social skills.
      • {% endif %} {% if autism3-14-recommendation == true %}
    • Utilizing similar language and prompts both at home and at school to help support {{ di-name }} when {% if di-gender == 'Boy' %}him {% else %}her {% endif %} perseverates and demonstrates difficulties with cognitive flexibility.
      • {% endif %} {% if autism3-15-recommendation == true %}
    • Consistency and reliability should be implemented as much as possible (i.e., same seat every day, predictable and logical flow/routine during the day).
      • {% endif %} {% if autism3-16-recommendation == true %}
    • Use of a timer as well to help with transitions between activities.
      • {% endif %} {% if autism3-17-recommendation == true %}
    • Schedule changes and transitions should be discussed ahead of time (as frequently as possible) to help {{ di-name }} shift activities and maintain a sense of control.
      • {% endif %} {% if autism3-18-recommendation == true %}
    • It would be beneficial for {{ di-name }}’s parents to schedule an IEP meeting, to revise {{ di-name }}’s previous IEP to reflect {% if di-gender == 'Boy' %}his {% else %}her {% endif %} diagnosis of Autism Spectrum Disorder. It is important for the educational staff to be aware of {{ di-name }}’s difficulties socially, as well as {% if di-gender == 'Boy' %}his {% else %}her {% endif %} difficulties sustaining attention. Because of {% if di-gender == 'Boy' %}his {% else %}her {% endif %} tendency to be very verbal, others may not readily recognize that {{ di-name }} has significant difficulty understanding and interpreting social cues.
      • {% endif %}
    • {% endif %} {% if autism4-recommendation == true %}
  • {{ di-name }} will be successful when the environment has consistent structure and expectations. As a result, both home and school environments should help create a similar sense of structure.
    • {% endif %} {% if autism5-recommendation == true %}
  • Due to {{ di-name }}’s rigidity, parents should provide a structured environment at home that encourages success and models effective coping strategies.
    • {% endif %} {% if autism6-recommendation == true %}
  • {{ di-name }} would benefit from increasing {% if di-gender == 'Boy' %}his {% else %}her {% endif %}understanding of social relationships and {% if di-gender == 'Boy' %}his {% else %}her {% endif %}insight into how to make and maintain peer relationships. This training may best be implemented in a group setting where {{ di-name }} has an opportunity to practice skills under the supervision of a trained facilitator.
    • {% endif %} {% if autism7-recommendation == true %}
  • {{ di-name }} would benefit from participation in a social skills group targeted toward teaching more complex social skills, such as understanding the pragmatics of social communication, perspective taking, and initiating and maintaining conversations about non-preferred topics. An individual therapist would also be helpful to review the specific social skills in a one to one setting.
    • {% endif %} {% if autism8-recommendation == true %}
  • {{ di-parent-name }} should model and rehearse with {{ di-name }} appropriate social skills, to help {% if di-gender == 'Boy' %}him {% else %}her {% endif %}use the skills when away from home.
    • {% endif %} {% if autism9-recommendation == true %}
  • {{ di-name }} would benefit from opportunities to practice {% if di-gender == 'Boy' %}his {% else %}her {% endif %}social skills in informal settings, such as outings with peers. Outings should be time limited (no more than 1-2 hours) and involve 1-2 peers to start. Activities should be selected in advance and should be activities that {{ di-name }} enjoys and that promote social engagement.
    • {% endif %} {% if autism10-recommendation == true %}
  • It is recommended that {{ di-name }} be involved in activities that foster {% if di-gender == 'Boy' %}his {% else %}her {% endif %}social development, to further increase {% if di-gender == 'Boy' %}his {% else %}her {% endif %}social skills. Enrolling {{ di-name }} in activities that {% if di-gender == 'Boy' %}he {% else %}she {% endif %}enjoys would help {% if di-gender == 'Boy' %}his {% else %}her {% endif %}social development and may help to increase {% if di-gender == 'Boy' %}his {% else %}her {% endif %}overall self-esteem.
    • {% endif %} {% if autism11-recommendation == true %}
  • Lastly, {{ di-name }} and {% if di-gender == 'Boy' %}his {% else %}her {% endif %}family may also find additional support and resources at the following websites:
      {% if autism11-1-recommendation == true %}
    • National Resource Center on ADHD www.help4adhd.org
      • {% endif %} {% if autism11-2-recommendation == true %}
    • Autism speaks: www.autismspeaks.org
      • {% endif %} {% if autism11-3-recommendation == true %}
    • Michelle Winner’s Social Thinking program emphasizes how to be a part of the group, how to have conversations (topics other than the individual’s special interests), and perspective taking. http://www.socialthinking.com
      • {% endif %} {% if autism11-4-recommendation == true %}
    • www.danielwendler.com for tips and a resource guide to improving social skills
      • {% endif %} {% if autism11-5-recommendation == true %}
    • www.nationalautismassociation.org
      • {% endif %} {% if autism11-6-recommendation == true %}
    • Autism Society of America: www.autism-society.org
      • {% endif %} {% if autism11-7-recommendation == true %}
    • www.autismnow.org
      • {% endif %} {% if autism11-8-recommendation == true %}
    • www.autismtasks.com for online activities
      • {% endif %} {% if autism11-9-recommendation == true %}
    • Let’s Face It: www.web.uvic.ca/~letsface/letsfaceit - teaches facial and emotional recognition
      • {% endif %}
    • {% endif %}
{% if autism-recommendations-freehand != undefined %}

Additional Autism recommendations: {{ autism-recommendations-freehand }}

{% endif %}
{% endif %} {% if recommendation-dementia == true %}

DEMENTIA

    {% if dementia1-recommendation == true %}
  • {{ di-name }}'s current symptoms negatively impact {% if di-gender == 'Boy' %}his {% else %}her {% endif %}daily functioning and could be exacerbated by increased amounts of stress. {% if di-gender == 'Boy' %}His {% else %}Her {% endif %}occupational and adaptive functioning have been greatly reduced and {% if di-gender == 'Boy' %}he {% else %}she {% endif %}requires assistance to assist with functioning in these domains.
      {% if dementia1-1-recommendation == true %}
    • It is recommended that {{ di-name }} seek disability services to help with current coping and additional supportive services over time.
      • {% endif %} {% if dementia1-2-recommendation == true %}
    • It is also suggested that {{ di-name }} seek consultation with {% if di-gender == 'Boy' %}his {% else %}her {% endif %}employee assistance team to help {% if di-gender == 'Boy' %}him {% else %}her {% endif %}navigate {% if di-gender == 'Boy' %}his {% else %}her {% endif %}current needs as they pertain to {% if di-gender == 'Boy' %}his {% else %}her {% endif %}work environment.
      • {% endif %} {% if dementia1-3-recommendation == true %}
    • {{ di-name }} are encouraged to talk about financial planning and goals for the current time as well as the future if {{ di-name }} should experience increasing cognitive and adaptive functioning challenges.
      • {% endif %}
    • {% endif %} {% if dementia2-recommendation == true %}
  • It is of paramount importance that {{ di-name }} seeks out additional medical consultation in order to rule out any reversible medical causes for {% if di-gender == 'Boy' %}his {% else %}her {% endif %}current dementia symptoms.
    • {% endif %} {% if dementia3-recommendation == true %}
  • {{ di-name }} will benefit from the use of the following additional organizational strategies that {% if di-gender == 'Boy' %}he {% else %}she {% endif %}can implement into {% if di-gender == 'Boy' %}his {% else %}her {% endif %}daily routines:
      {% if dementia3-1-recommendation == true %}
    • Using an alarm on {% if di-gender == 'Boy' %}his {% else %}her {% endif %}mobile device to set important reminders.
      • {% endif %} {% if dementia3-2-recommendation == true %}
    • Utilize a checklist when having to complete multiple tasks.
      • {% endif %} {% if dementia3-3-recommendation == true %}
    • Create structure for time management that allows for individual tasks to be focused on.
      • {% endif %}
    • {% endif %} {% if dementia4-recommendation == true %}
  • {{ di-name }} will benefit from individual therapy in order to process and support the impact that {% if di-gender == 'Boy' %}his {% else %}her {% endif %}cognitive decline has on {% if di-gender == 'Boy' %}his {% else %}her {% endif %}level of functioning currently and in the future. This support could help {% if di-gender == 'Boy' %}him {% else %}her {% endif %}develop effective coping strategies to manage {% if di-gender == 'Boy' %}his {% else %}her {% endif %}symptoms of anxiety and depression.
    • {% endif %} {% if dementia5-recommendation == true %}
  • {{ di-name }} may also wish to consider neurofeedback as a source of self-regulation that can assist with cognitive (e.g., inattention, motivation), physical (e.g., pain) and emotional challenges (e.g., depression, anxiety).
    • {% endif %} {% if dementia6-recommendation == true %}
  • {{ di-name }} may also benefit from participating in a support group for adults experiencing cognitive decline, anxiety, and depression. This group could help support {{ di-name }} in improving {% if di-gender == 'Boy' %}his {% else %}her {% endif %}mood by helping {% if di-gender == 'Boy' %}him {% else %}her {% endif %}to increase {% if di-gender == 'Boy' %}his {% else %}her {% endif %}social support and coping skills.
    • {% endif %} {% if dementia7-recommendation == true %}
  • {{ di-name }} and {% if di-gender == 'Boy' %}his {% else %}her {% endif %}family might wish to participate in family therapy in order to process the impact that {% if di-gender == 'Boy' %}his {% else %}her {% endif %}symptoms have on each individual and the relationships within their system.
    • {% endif %} {% if dementia8-recommendation == true %}
  • {{ di-name }} and {% if di-gender == 'Boy' %}his {% else %}her {% endif %}family should utilize the education and support provided by the following groups and organizations:
    • Seven Stages of Dementia | Symptoms & Progression: https://www.dementiacarecentral.com/aboutdementia/facts/stages/
    • Caregivers Guide to Understanding Dementia:
      https://www.caregiver.org/caregivers-guide-understanding-dementia-behaviors
    • Support and Local Programs for individuals with Dementia: http://www.alz.org/mnnd/in_my_community_18497.asp
    • {% endif %} {% if dementia9-recommendation == true %}
  • {{ di-name }} will benefit from additional organizational strategies:
    • Using an alarm on {% if di-gender == 'Boy' %}his {% else %}her {% endif %}mobile device to set important reminders.
    • Create a checklist of slides when giving a presentation.
    • Utilize a checklist when having to complete multiple tasks.
    • Create structure for time management that allows for individual tasks to be focused on before moving on to the next task.
    • {% endif %} {% if dementia10-recommendation == true %}
  • {{ di-name }} should continue to frequently engage in self-care activities (i.e., exercise, hobbies, spending time with friends) to help improve {% if di-gender == 'Boy' %}his {% else %}her {% endif %}mood, sense of connectedness, and to better manage {% if di-gender == 'Boy' %}his {% else %}her {% endif %}stress on a day-to-day basis.
    • {% endif %}
{% if dementia-recommendations-freehand != undefined %}

Additional Dementia recommendations: {{ dementia-recommendations-freehand }}

{% endif %}
{% endif %} {% if recommendation-dysthymia == true %}

Dysthymia

    {% if dysthymia1-recommendation == true %}
  • {{ di-name }}’s current symptoms negatively impact {% if di-gender == 'Boy' %}his {% else %}her {% endif %}daily functioning and are exacerbated by increased amounts of stress. At this time, {{ di-name }} would benefit from a psychiatric medication consultation to evaluate whether {% if di-gender == 'Boy' %}his {% else %}her {% endif %}current medications are effectively treating {% if di-gender == 'Boy' %}his {% else %}her {% endif %}mood symptoms.
    • {% endif %} {% if dysthymia2-recommendation == true %}
  • {{ di-name }} should continue to utilize {% if di-gender == 'Boy' %}his {% else %}her {% endif %}individual therapeutic supports to help {% if di-gender == 'Boy' %}him {% else %}her {% endif %}develop effective coping strategies to manage {% if di-gender == 'Boy' %}his {% else %}her {% endif %}symptoms of anxiety and depression.
    • {% endif %} {% if dysthymia3-recommendation == true %}
  • {{ di-name }} may also benefit from participating in a support group for adults experiencing anxiety and depression. This group could help support {{ di-name }} in improving {% if di-gender == 'Boy' %}his {% else %}her {% endif %}mood by helping {% if di-gender == 'Boy' %}him {% else %}her {% endif %}to increase {% if di-gender == 'Boy' %}his {% else %}her {% endif %}social support and coping skills.
    • {% endif %} {% if dysthymia4-recommendation == true %}
  • {{ di-name }} may also benefit from participating in Neurofeedback to help {% if di-gender == 'Boy' %}him {% else %}her {% endif %}better regulate {% if di-gender == 'Boy' %}his {% else %}her {% endif %}symptoms of depression, inattention and anxiety. Neurofeedback is considered a natural treatment for improving attention and self-regulation for individuals who want to take a medication free approach to treatment or to enhance the effects of other treatments they are already receiving.
    • {% endif %} {% if dysthymia5-recommendation == true %}
  • {{ di-name }} should frequently engage in self-care activities (i.e., exercise, hobbies, spending time with friends) to help improve {% if di-gender == 'Boy' %}his {% else %}her {% endif %}mood, sense of connectedness, and to better manage {% if di-gender == 'Boy' %}his {% else %}her {% endif %}stress on a day-to-day basis.
    • {% endif %}
{% if dysthymia-recommendations-freehand != undefined %}

Additional Dysthymia recommendations: {{ dysthymia-recommendations-freehand }}

{% endif %}
{% endif %} {% if recommendation-learning-disability-mathematics == true %}

Learning Disability Mathematics

    {% if learning-disability-mathematics1-recommendation == true %}
  • {{ di-name }}’s mother should review the findings from this evaluation to gain an understanding of {{ di-name }}’s current psychoeducational strengths and limitations and to implement appropriate recommendations and mobilize necessary services to assist with the provision of continued accommodations as {% if di-gender == 'Boy' %}he {% else %}she {% endif %}transitions to adulthood.
    • {% endif %} {% if learning-disability-mathematics2-recommendation == true %}
  • It is recommended that {{ di-name }}’s mother provide this evaluation to individuals at {% if di-gender == 'Boy' %}his {% else %}her {% endif %}school as well as standardized assessment centers so that {% if di-gender == 'Boy' %}he {% else %}she {% endif %}can receive ongoing accommodations that will enable {% if di-gender == 'Boy' %}him {% else %}her {% endif %}to more fully demonstrate {% if di-gender == 'Boy' %}his {% else %}her {% endif %}abilities and access the learning materials {% if di-gender == 'Boy' %}he {% else %}she {% endif %}is provided.
    • {% endif %} {% if learning-disability-mathematics3-recommendation == true %}
  • {{ di-name }} should be provided with access to double time on all standardized assessments with the provision of extra breaks to prevent fatigue and subsequent inattention.
    • {% endif %} {% if learning-disability-mathematics4-recommendation == true %}
  • {{ di-name }} should be provided with the opportunity to have all test instructions read out loud to ensure that {% if di-gender == 'Boy' %}he {% else %}she {% endif %}understands what the assignment requires.
    • {% endif %} {% if learning-disability-mathematics5-recommendation == true %}
  • {{ di-name }} should be provided with the opportunity to take all standardized testing and large classroom-based assessments in a separate and quiet location with limited opportunities for distraction.
    • {% endif %} {% if learning-disability-mathematics6-recommendation == true %}
  • It is important that {{ di-name }} is provided with an academic advisor when {% if di-gender == 'Boy' %}he {% else %}she {% endif %}starts {% if di-gender == 'Boy' %}his {% else %}her {% endif %}post- secondary education so {% if di-gender == 'Boy' %}he {% else %}she {% endif %}can balance {% if di-gender == 'Boy' %}his {% else %}her {% endif %}schedule with less demanding courses to avoid emotional and cognitive overwhelm. {{ di-name }} should be allowed to sign up for classes early, whenever possible, to ensure that {% if di-gender == 'Boy' %}he {% else %}she {% endif %}is enrolled in appropriate classes that will afford {% if di-gender == 'Boy' %}him {% else %}her {% endif %}ongoing ability to achieve at a more optimal level.
    • {% endif %} {% if learning-disability-mathematics7-recommendation == true %}
  • {{ di-name }} should be provided with outlines of course material prior to class so {% if di-gender == 'Boy' %}he {% else %}she {% endif %}has less demands placed on writing and {% if di-gender == 'Boy' %}he {% else %}she {% endif %}will be able to allocate more energy to sustaining attention to classroom-based discussion.
    • {% endif %} {% if learning-disability-mathematics8-recommendation == true %}
  • {{ di-name }} will benefit from consistent support that will help reduce demands for independent executive function. This type of support will help bridge the gap between childhood and adulthood and allow {{ di-name }}’s mother to step back and for appropriate community resources to be implemented.
    • {% endif %} {% if learning-disability-mathematics9-recommendation == true %}
  • {{ di-name }} should be encouraged to seek healthy, fun, and therapeutic ways to manage {% if di-gender == 'Boy' %}his {% else %}her {% endif %}social communication, executive, and emotional symptoms. {{ di-name }} should consider trying the following approaches:
      {% if learning-disability-mathematics9-1-recommendation == true %}
    • Neurofeedback
      • {{ di-name }} would also benefit from participating in Neurofeedback. With neurofeedback we are enhancing awareness of internal states by allowing the brain to witness its own EEG activity. The goal is to allow the nervous system to calm down and reset itself onto a better path. Neurofeedback is considered a natural treatment for improving attention and self-regulation for individuals who want to take a medication free approach to treatment or to enhance the effects of other treatments they are already receiving. It also addresses and better regulates symptoms of inattention and anxiety.
      • {% endif %} {% if learning-disability-mathematics9-2-recommendation == true %}
    • Mediation Practices and Mindfulness
      • Meditation practice involving attention to ones breathing have been used for centuries. Mindfulness involves experiencing life from moment to moment with full awareness and acceptance and a practice that teaches us to pay greater attention to our internal and external experience.
      • These practices can guide individuals to improve relationships, create relaxation and calmness, sooth the self, increase memory, enhance focus, reduce stress, manage reactions and emotions, increase self-acceptance, and feel more at ease.
      • {% endif %} {% if learning-disability-mathematics9-3-recommendation == true %}
    • Breathing and Progressive Relaxation
      • {{ di-name }} can be taught how to take conscious deep breaths to relax while listening to the sound of air coming in and out. {% if di-gender == 'Boy' %}He {% else %}She {% endif %}should be shown how to inhale deeply (preferably through the nose) and slowly exhale through the mouth. The abdomen rises and expands during inhaling.
      • {{ di-name }} can learn progressive muscle relaxation by isolating different body parts and then tightening and relaxing them.
      • {% endif %} {% if learning-disability-mathematics9-4-recommendation == true %}
    • Yoga and Other Controlled Exercises
      • Yoga has many health and psychological benefits, among them stress reduction and heightening one’s focus and self-awareness.
      • {% endif %} {% if learning-disability-mathematics9-5-recommendation == true %}
    • Guided Imagery and Visualization
      • The ability to visualize colorful, vivid images with rich imagination can help empower individuals to overcome obstacles in their lives.
      • These techniques can be used for improving memory and learning, facilitate healing, and strength other areas of functioning such as social skills, coping, and creative expression.
      • {% endif %} {% if learning-disability-mathematics9-7-recommendation == true %}
    • Exercise and Physical Activity
      • Exercise stimulates the central nervous system by increasing blood flow and oxygen to the brain.
      • Exercise strengthens muscles, improves coordination, builds stamina, elevates mood, and is a positive outlet for excessive energy.
      • {% endif %} {% if learning-disability-mathematics9-8-recommendation == true %}
    • Green Time
      • Several studies have shown that exposure to green, outdoor settings – a tree lined street, park, or grassy backyard – helps individuals with executive dysfunction feel calmer and more focused that those who spend hours on the computer or within an asphalt or concrete environment.
      • {% endif %} {% if learning-disability-mathematics9-9-recommendation == true %}
    • Music
      • Music is well known to have many positive benefits in addition to pleasure and enjoyment.
      • Many individuals find that they are better able to focus and are more motivated and productive when listening to music.
      • Neuroscience is learning more and more about the effects of auditory stimulation on the brain. Music therapy may bolster attention and focus, reduce impulsivity, and strengthen social skills.
      • {% endif %} {% if learning-disability-mathematics9-10-recommendation == true %}
    • Art
      • Any opportunity to give individuals creative outlets that they find pleasurable is well worth pursuing. {{ di-name }} as many other young adults with executive dysfunction has artistic strengths.
      • Drawing, painting, sculpting, photography, and other forms of visual art expression can have very beneficial effects.
      • Painting, drawing, and sculpting are great hands-on treatment for calming mind and body.
      • The visual arts are a means of self-expression and enable one to express graphically what may be difficult to do verbally, such as talking about feelings and emotions.
      • Art therapy is based on the premise that self-expression can be used to address emotional problems, develop interpersonal skills, manage behavior, reduce stress, and increase and increase self-awareness.
      • Different parts of the brain are engaged when painting, drawing, and sculpting, for example, those involved in motor skills, attention, and working memory.
      • {{ di-name }} will benefit from ongoing participation in structured group activities where {% if di-gender == 'Boy' %}he {% else %}she {% endif %}can continue to develop {% if di-gender == 'Boy' %}his {% else %}her {% endif %}peer-relational and social communication skills.
      • {% endif %}
    • {% endif %} {% if learning-disability-mathematics-recommendations-freehand != undefined %}

    Additional Learning Disability Mathematics recommendations: {{ learning-disability-mathematics-recommendations-freehand }}

    {% endif %}
{% endif %} {% if recommendation-learning-disability-reading == true %}

Learning Disability Reading

    {% if learning-disability-reading1-recommendation == true %}
  • {{ di-name }}’s parents should share the results of this evaluation with {% if di-gender == 'Boy' %}his {% else %}her {% endif %}current educators and the following recommendations should be incorporated into {% if di-gender == 'Boy' %}his {% else %}her {% endif %}academic environment. Results of this assessment should also be shared with future schools to which {% if di-gender == 'Boy' %}he {% else %}she {% endif %}gains admittance as soon as possible so {% if di-gender == 'Boy' %}he {% else %}she {% endif %}can receive assistance with class selection and to determine how to incorporate the necessary accommodations into {% if di-gender == 'Boy' %}his {% else %}her {% endif %}regular schedule.
    • {% endif %} {% if learning-disability-reading2-recommendation == true %}
  • {{ di-name }} should talk to each of {% if di-gender == 'Boy' %}his {% else %}her {% endif %}teachers during the first weeks of class to determine how to access office hour support and to discuss {% if di-gender == 'Boy' %}his {% else %}her {% endif %}needs and accommodations.
    • {% endif %} {% if learning-disability-reading3-recommendation == true %}
  • {{ di-name }}'s current testing results documented {% if di-gender == 'Boy' %}his {% else %}her {% endif %}relative weakness with inattention, impulsivity, and reading comprehension. It is recommended that {% if di-gender == 'Boy' %}he {% else %}she {% endif %}receive 50% extended testing time on tests and examinations to help {% if di-gender == 'Boy' %}him {% else %}her {% endif %}illustrate {% if di-gender == 'Boy' %}his {% else %}her {% endif %}knowledge base to the best of {% if di-gender == 'Boy' %}his {% else %}her {% endif %}ability. Extended time would help {{ di-name }} access the full scope of the material presented to {% if di-gender == 'Boy' %}him {% else %}her {% endif %} check {% if di-gender == 'Boy' %}his {% else %}her {% endif %}work, and allow {% if di-gender == 'Boy' %}him {% else %}her {% endif %}the needed time to process the testing material.
    • {% endif %} {% if learning-disability-reading4-recommendation == true %}
  • Specifically, due to {% if di-gender == 'Boy' %}his {% else %}her {% endif %}aforementioned weaknesses, {% if di-gender == 'Boy' %}he {% else %}she {% endif %}also requires 50% extended testing time on all in-class tests.
    • {% endif %} {% if learning-disability-reading5-recommendation == true %}
  • {{ di-name }}'s functional impairments also require that {% if di-gender == 'Boy' %}he {% else %}she {% endif %}be allowed to take examinations in a distraction reduced environment.
    • {% endif %} {% if learning-disability-reading6-recommendation == true %}
  • Furthermore, while in the classroom, {{ di-name }} should be encouraged to sit close to the teacher/speaker, and further from {% if di-gender == 'Boy' %}his {% else %}her {% endif %}preferred peers, to help guard against lapses in {% if di-gender == 'Boy' %}his {% else %}her {% endif %}attention and concentration.
    • {% endif %} {% if learning-disability-reading7-recommendation == true %}
  • {{ di-name }} would also benefit from having an end of the day study hall at school to help {% if di-gender == 'Boy' %}him {% else %}her {% endif %}complete {% if di-gender == 'Boy' %}his {% else %}her {% endif %}work.
    • {% endif %} {% if learning-disability-reading8-recommendation == true %}
  • It also will be helpful for {{ di-name }} to utilize a homework routine to help {% if di-gender == 'Boy' %}him {% else %}her {% endif %}accomplish {% if di-gender == 'Boy' %}his {% else %}her {% endif %}nightly tasks. For example, {{ di-name }} should allow herself, at most, one hour after school to decompress before starting {% if di-gender == 'Boy' %}his {% else %}her {% endif %}homework. To help {% if di-gender == 'Boy' %}him {% else %}her {% endif %}, {% if di-gender == 'Boy' %}he {% else %}she {% endif %}could also utilize an alarm on {% if di-gender == 'Boy' %}his {% else %}her {% endif %}phone to signal when the hour is up so that {% if di-gender == 'Boy' %}he {% else %}she {% endif %}does not lose track of time. (This can also be utilized while taking breaks in between assignments). To help {% if di-gender == 'Boy' %}him {% else %}her {% endif %}stay motivated, {{ di-name }} could also reward {% if di-gender == 'Boy' %}himself {% else %}herself {% endif %}during {% if di-gender == 'Boy' %}his {% else %}her {% endif %}breaks by watching a preferred, short TV show or spending 15-30 minutes in a preferred activity. On days that {% if di-gender == 'Boy' %}he {% else %}she {% endif %}has volleyball practices and/or games, {{ di-name }} should utilize the time right after school to begin {% if di-gender == 'Boy' %}his {% else %}her {% endif %}work before engaging with peers and starting sports practice.
    • {% endif %} {% if learning-disability-reading9-recommendation == true %}
  • {{ di-name }} is encouraged to continue utilizing a schedule/planner daily to help {% if di-gender == 'Boy' %}him {% else %}her {% endif %}keep track of important due dates, appointments, and school assignments.
    • {% endif %} {% if learning-disability-reading10-recommendation == true %}
  • Similarly, {{ di-name }} would greatly benefit from continuing to learn and utilizing organizational techniques (i.e., making lists, brainstorming verbally, breaking down larger tasks into smaller components) to help {% if di-gender == 'Boy' %}him {% else %}her {% endif %}better manage {% if di-gender == 'Boy' %}his {% else %}her {% endif %}assignments and tasks.
    • {% endif %} {% if learning-disability-reading11-recommendation == true %}
  • While reading, {{ di-name }} should practice and engage in active reading skills (e.g., underlining, taking notes simultaneously to help {% if di-gender == 'Boy' %}him {% else %}her {% endif %}grasp main ideas vs. supporting details) to help {% if di-gender == 'Boy' %}him {% else %}her {% endif %}comprehend reading passages.
    • {% endif %} {% if learning-disability-reading12-recommendation == true %}
  • {{ di-name }} would also benefit from participating in Neurofeedback to help {% if di-gender == 'Boy' %}him {% else %}her {% endif %}better regulate {% if di-gender == 'Boy' %}his {% else %}her {% endif %}symptoms of inattention, impulsivity, disorganization, and anxiety. Neurofeedback is considered a natural treatment for improving attention and self-regulation for individuals who want to take a medication free approach to treatment or to enhance the effects of other treatments they are already receiving.
    • {% endif %} {% if learning-disability-reading13-recommendation == true %}
  • Breathing and Progressive Relaxation: {{ di-name }} can be taught how to take conscious deep breaths to relax while listening to the sound of air coming in and out. {% if di-gender == 'Boy' %}He {% else %}She {% endif %}should be shown how to inhale deeply (preferably through the nose) and slowly exhale through the mouth. The abdomen rises and expands during inhaling.

    {{ di-name }} can learn progressive muscle relaxation by isolating different body parts and then tightening and relaxing them.
    • {% endif %}
{% if learning-disability-reading-recommendations-freehand != undefined %}

Additional Learning Disability Reading recommendations: {{ learning-disability-reading-recommendations-freehand }}

{% endif %}
{% endif %} {% if recommendation-neurocognitive-disorder == true %}

Neurocognitive Disorder

    {% if neurocognitive-disorder1-recommendation == true %}
  • Therapeutic pre-school specifically designed for children with severe behavioral difficulties. These pre-schools have small class sizes and are equipped to address the significant behavioral and emotional issues.
    • {% endif %} {% if neurocognitive-disorder2-recommendation == true %}
  • In addressing emotional functioning and anger symptoms it is recommended that:
      {% if neurocognitive-disorder2-1-recommendation == true %}
    • Utilize a variety of therapeutic interventions to promote relaxation and emotional regulation in addition to behavioral techniques. These can include:
      • Mindfulness and mediation practices involving attention to his breathing and internal and external experience. For example, utilizing the Spider-Man Mindfulness script incorporates using several senses, including tactile, auditory, and olfactory senses.
      • Relaxation techniques including diaphragmatic breathing exercises and progressive muscle relaxation techniques.
      • Yoga and other controlled exercises.
      • Exposure to green, outdoor settings may help Devon feel calmer and more relaxed.
      • {% endif %}
    • {% endif %} {% if neurocognitive-disorder3-recommendation == true %}
  • In addressing impulsive behaviors, self-control, and body-control/awareness, he/she may benefit from occupational therapy. Occupational therapy can also assess if {{ di-name }} experiences any sensory processing difficulties which may be contributing to {% if di-gender == 'Boy' %}his {% else %}her {% endif %}hyperactivity, impulsivity, and attentional difficulties.
    • {% endif %}
{% if neurocognitive-disorder-recommendations-freehand != undefined %}

Additional Neurocognitive Disorder recommendations: {{ neurocognitive-disorder-recommendations-freehand }}

{% endif %}
{% endif %} {% if recommendation-visual-processing-children-adults == true %}

Visual Processing Weakness for Children & Adults

    {% if visual-processing-children-adults1-recommendation == true %}
  • Results from the assessment report should be shared with others invested in the client’s treatment and wellbeing (e.g. physicians, caregivers, educators, therapists, etc.) to encourage a multi-disciplinary, oriented treatment approach.
    • {% endif %} {% if visual-processing-children-adults2-recommendation == true %}
  • Given that the client’s adaptive functioning is impacted by a visual processing weakness, they may benefit from working with a psychotherapist to process frustration and an impacted self-esteem around this. The client would benefit from meeting with a therapist to address these issues on a weekly basis for a minimum of 45 minutes. Another area that may be addressed within the client’s work with a therapist building upon frustration tolerance around the client’s current areas of difficulty
    • {% endif %} {% if visual-processing-children-adults3-recommendation == true %}
  • The client would benefit from an evaluation with an optometrist, ophthalmologist, or behavioral optometrist to gain diagnostic clarification around ocular functioning surrounding or informing the client’s apparent visual processing weakness. Additionally, the client would benefit from engaging in recommended interventions put forward by them.
    • {% endif %} {% if visual-processing-children-adults4-recommendation == true %}
  • The client may benefit from an evaluation with an Occupational Therapist around possible deficits in visual-motor tasks given their visual processing weaknesses. Furthermore they may benefit from suggested appropriate sensory-related recommendations put forward.
    • {% endif %} {% if visual-processing-children-adults5-recommendation == true %}
  • The client may also benefit from consulting with professionals at Irlen testing centers to address a potential visual processing deficit. More info regarding the services offered at these centers can be found at: https://irlen.com/find-an-irlen-test-center/.
    • {% endif %} {% if visual-processing-children-adults6-recommendation == true %}
  • Re-assessment and monitoring the client’s progress around their challenges in visual processing weaknesses is recommended to re-evaluate current strengths and weakness, and to provide updated appropriate treatment intervention recommendations.
    • {% endif %}
{% if visual-processing-weakness-for-children-&-adults-recommendations-freehand != undefined %}

Additional Visual Processing Weakness for Children & Adults recommendations: {{ neurocognitive-disorder-recommendations-freehand }}

{% endif %}
{% endif %} {% if recommendation-visual-processing-children == true %}

Visual Processing Weakness for Children & Adults

    {% if visual-processing-children1-recommendation == true %}
  • The client’s caregivers can choose to convene a meeting with the Committee on Special Education (CSE) to consider establishing an Individualized Education Program (IEP) under the classification of Specific Learning Disability (SLD), given the client’s symptoms are significantly impacting their access to the curriculum and educational performance.
      {% if visual-processing-children2-1-recommendation == true %}
    • Given the client’s overall cognitive abilities, they should be placed in a school setting with students of the same or higher intellectual potential.
      • {% endif %} {% if visual-processing-children2-2-recommendation == true %}
    • Consider seating the client at the front of the classroom, close to the teacher.
      • {% endif %} {% if visual-processing-children2-3-recommendation == true %}
    • The client should receive extra time when completing reading-based tasks.
      • {% endif %} {% if visual-processing-children2-4-recommendation == true %}
    • The client may benefit from access to multi-sensory learning materials, which may allow them to take in information in various ways. These may include audio-books.
      • {% endif %} {% if visual-processing-children2-5-recommendation == true %}
    • Consider providing the client with jobs or classroom chores to foster their sense of inclusion, responsibility, and engagement in the class despite their academic challenges.
      • {% endif %} {% if visual-processing-children2-6-recommendation == true %}
    • The client would benefit from receiving instructional support within small groups and a low student-to-teacher ratio specifically around writing tasks.
      • {% endif %} {% if visual-processing-children2-7-recommendation == true %}
    • It is suggested that the client be allowed to re-read and refer back to the text.
      • {% endif %} {% if visual-processing-children2-8-recommendation == true %}
    • The client may benefit from strategies derived from approaches such as Orton-Gillingham or Lindamood Bell to enhance any impairment in reading. This multisensory remediation approach to improve reading decoding may assist the client if faced with difficulties in processing written information.
      • {% endif %} {% if visual-processing-children2-9-recommendation == true %}
    • If recommended the use of colored inlay sheets to assist mitigate visual processing deficits by Irlen testing centers, the client should be able to utilize throughout academic tasks in their learning environment.
      • {% endif %}
    • {% endif %} {% if visual-processing-children-adults2-recommendation == true %}
  • The client’s caregivers should play an active role in understanding the client’s visual processing weaknesses and associated limitations given their current difficulties in writing. In turn, the client’s caregivers should maintain realistic expectations and ensure not to punish or reprimand the client for failure to complete associated tasks.
    • {% endif %}
{% if visual-processing-weakness-for-children-recommendations-freehand != undefined %}

Additional Visual Processing Weakness for Children recommendations: {{ visual-processing-weakness-for-children-recommendations-freehand }}

{% endif %}
{% endif %} {% if recommendation-learning-disability-writing-children-adults == true %}

Learning Disability in Writing Diagnosis for Children & Adults

    {% if learning-disability-writing-children-adults1-recommendation == true %}
  • Results from the assessment report should be shared with others invested in the client’s treatment and wellbeing (e.g. physicians, caregivers, educators, therapists, etc.) to encourage a multi-disciplinary, oriented treatment approach.
    • {% endif %} {% if learning-disability-writing-children-adults2-recommendation == true %}
  • Given that the client’s adaptive functioning is negatively impacted by specific challenges in writing, they may benefit from working with a psychotherapist to process frustration and an impacted self-esteem around this. The client would benefit from meeting with a therapist to address these issues on a weekly basis for a minimum of 45 minutes. Another area that may be addressed within the client’s work with a therapist are building upon frustration tolerance around the client’s current areas of difficulty.
    • {% endif %} {% if learning-disability-writing-children-adults3-recommendation == true %}
  • The client would benefit from an evaluation with an optometrist, ophthalmologist, or behavioral optometrist to rule out any visual deficits, which may be negatively impacting the client’s writing abilities. Furthermore, the client would benefit from engaging in recommended interventions put forward by them.
    • {% endif %} {% if learning-disability-writing-children-adults4-recommendation == true %}
  • The client may benefit from an assessment with an Occupational Therapist to consider any sensory implications that may be impacting their ongoing writing difficulties as well as potential sensory-related interventions that may further assist them in this domain.
    • {% endif %} {% if learning-disability-writing-children-adults5-recommendation == true %}
  • Re-assessment and monitoring the client’s progress around their challenges in writing is recommended to re-evaluate current strengths and weakness, and to provide updated appropriate treatment intervention recommendations.
    • {% endif %}
{% if learning-disability-in-writing-diagnosis-for-children-&-adults-recommendations-freehand != undefined %}

Additional Learning Disability in Writing Diagnosis for Children & Adults recommendations: {{ learning-disability-in-writing-diagnosis-for-children-&-adults-recommendations-freehand }}

{% endif %}
{% endif %} {% if recommendation-learning-disability-writing-children == true %}

Learning Disability in Writing Diagnosis for Children

    {% if learning-disability-writing-children1-recommendation == true %}
  • The client’s caregivers can choose to convene a meeting with the Committee on Special Education (CSE) to consider establishing an Individualized Education Program (IEP) under the classification of Specific Learning Disability (SLD), given the client’s symptoms are significantly impacting their access to the curriculum and educational performance.
      {% if learning-disability-writing-children1-1-recommendation == true %}
    • Given the client’s overall cognitive abilities, they should be placed in a school setting with students of the same or higher intellectual potential.
      • {% endif %} {% if learning-disability-writing-children1-2-recommendation == true %}
    • Consider seating the client at the front of the classroom, close to the teacher.
      • {% endif %} {% if learning-disability-writing-children1-3-recommendation == true %}
    • The client should receive extra time when completing writing-based tasks.
      • {% endif %} {% if learning-disability-writing-children1-4-recommendation == true %}
    • The client should have access to text-to-speech technology such as Kurzweil 3000.
      • {% endif %} {% if learning-disability-writing-children1-5-recommendation == true %}
    • The client would benefit from engaging in evidence-based strategies that can be implemented to address the various cognitive processes that can cause writing difficulties. Given that the nature of writing difficulties varies from case to case (sensory/kinesthetic, sensory/motor integration, or pure motor problem), targeted evidence-based interventions should address individual child needs. These evidence-based strategies include:
      • Strategies for improving spelling accuracy
        • Utilizing graph paper to assist motor coordination and visual-motor integration of handwriting (grades 1-5, or older children with spatial handwriting disability)
        • Cover-Copy-Compare: increases spelling proficiency through training and repetition (grades 2+)
        • Stay-Trace-Write Model: Uses oral language to assist with the learning of words with motor scripts
        • Self-Correction with Verbal Cues: Uses verbal self-talk to enhance written spelling accuracy (grades 2+)
      • Strategies for Promoting Written Expression
        • TOWER with COPS: Planning, organization, monitoring, and revision of work using TOWER (Thing, Organize, Write, Edit, Rewrite) approach when starting a writing task and COPS (Capitalization, Overall Appearance, Punctuation, Spelling) upon concluding writing task (grade 1+)
        • Sentence Combining: Using simple, active, affirmative declarative sentences with only one verb to develop more diverse and complex sentences using direct instruction (grades 2+)
        • Teacher-Directed Strategy Instruction: Teacher-directed strategy instruction of goal-setting, brainstorming, and organizing to assist in the writing process (grade 4)
        • Integrated Writing Instruction: Authentic sentences about life experiences to increase student engagement and motivation in writing (grade 6+)
        • PLEASE: A metacognitive strategy for idea generation, organization, composition and editing within writing (grade 6+)
        • PLAN and WRITE: Metacognitive strategy that helps student plan/organize their ideas. Helps students refer back to the goal of the assignment to aid in the writing process (grade 6-12)
      • {% endif %} {% if learning-disability-writing-children1-6-recommendation == true %}
    • Consider providing the client with jobs or classroom chores to foster their sense of inclusion, responsibility, and engagement in the class despite their academic challenges.
      • {% endif %} {% if learning-disability-writing-children1-7-recommendation == true %}
    • The client would benefit from receiving instructional support within small groups and a low student-to-teacher ratio specifically around writing tasks.
      • {% endif %}
    • {% endif %} {% if visual-processing-children-adults2-recommendation == true %}
  • The client’s caregivers should play an active role in understanding the client’s visual processing weaknesses and associated limitations given their current difficulties in writing. In turn, the client’s caregivers should maintain realistic expectations and ensure not to punish or reprimand the client for failure to complete associated tasks.
    • {% endif %}
{% if learning-disability-in-writing-diagnosis-for-children-recommendations-freehand != undefined %}

Additional Learning Disability in Writing Diagnosis for Children recommendations: {{ learning-disability-in-writing-diagnosis-for-children-recommendations-freehand }}

{% endif %}
{% endif %} {% if recommendation-auditory-processing-weakness-children-adults == true %}

Auditory Processing Weakness for Children & Adults

    {% if auditory-processing-weakness-children-adults1-recommendation == true %}
  • Results from the assessment report should be shared with others invested in the client’s treatment and wellbeing (e.g. physicians, caregivers, educators, therapists, etc.) to encourage a multi-disciplinary, oriented treatment approach.
    • {% endif %} {% if auditory-processing-weakness-children-adults2-recommendation == true %}
  • Given that the client’s adaptive functioning is impacted by an auditory processing weakness, they may benefit from working with a psychotherapist to process frustration and an impacted self-esteem around this. The client would benefit from meeting with a therapist to address these issues on a weekly basis for a minimum of 45 minutes. Another area that may be addressed within the client’s work with a therapist building upon frustration tolerance around the client’s current areas of difficulty.
    • {% endif %} {% if auditory-processing-weakness-children-adults3-recommendation == true %}
  • Psychotherapeutic / behavioral interventions aimed at improving the client’s assertiveness around their auditory processing limitations is recommended. These strategies may include the following:
      {% if auditory-processing-weakness-children-adults3-1-recommendation == true %}
    • Paraphrasing heard information during conversations to allow for better auditory processing.
      • {% endif %} {% if auditory-processing-weakness-children-adults3-2-recommendation == true %}
    • Requesting others to repeat their statements.
      • {% endif %} {% if auditory-processing-weakness-children-adults3-3-recommendation == true %}
    • Asking for background noise, such as music, to be turned off or lowered.
      • {% endif %}
    • {% endif %} {% if auditory-processing-weakness-children-adults4-recommendation == true %}
  • A consultation with a speech and language therapist is advised. Specifically, an evaluation with one such provider should focus on levels of phoneme perception and ability to appropriately use language in social settings. Following one such evaluation, appropriate interventions around improving active listening skills, phoneme perception, and adaptive communication, if any, should be recommended.
    • {% endif %} {% if auditory-processing-weakness-children-adults5-recommendation == true %}
  • The client may benefit from participating in a social skills group that focuses on improving verbal and non-verbal communication strategies. Within this context, the client may learn various ways to adaptively interact with others given challenges in auditory processing.
    • {% endif %} {% if auditory-processing-weakness-children-adults6-recommendation == true %}
  • The client is strongly advised to undergo an evaluation with an audiologist. Although auditory processing weaknesses are identified within the current testing data, an audiologist can only make the diagnosis of an auditory processing disorder. The client would also benefit from this evaluation to rule our organic auditory limitations and determine the appropriateness of supportive interventions or assistive devices.
    • {% endif %} {% if auditory-processing-weakness-children-adults7-recommendation == true %}
  • Re-assessment and monitoring the client’s progress around their challenges in visual processing weaknesses is recommended to re-evaluate current strengths and weakness, and to provide updated appropriate treatment intervention recommendations.
    • {% endif %}
{% if auditory-processing-weakness-for-children-&-adults-recommendations-freehand != undefined %}
