Additional Learning Disability in Writing Diagnosis for Children recommendations: {{ auditory-processing-weakness-for-children-&-adults-recommendations-freehand }}

{% endif %}
{% endif %} {% if recommendation-auditory-processing-weakness-children == true %}

Auditory Processing Weakness for Children

    {% if auditory-processing-weakness-children1-recommendation == true %}
  • The client’s caregivers can choose to convene a meeting with the Committee on Special Education (CSE) to consider establishing an Individualized Education Program (IEP) under the classification of Specific Learning Disability (SLD), given the client’s symptoms are significantly impacting their access to the curriculum and educational performance.
      {% if auditory-processing-weakness-children3-1-recommendation == true %}
    • Given the client’s overall cognitive abilities, they should be placed in a school setting with students of the same or higher intellectual potential.
      • {% endif %} {% if auditory-processing-weakness-children3-2-recommendation == true %}
    • Consider seating the client at the front of the classroom, close to the teacher.
      • {% endif %} {% if auditory-processing-weakness-children3-3-recommendation == true %}
    • The client should receive extra time when completing reading-based tasks.
      • {% endif %} {% if auditory-processing-weakness-children3-4-recommendation == true %}
    • The client may benefit from access to multi-sensory learning materials, which may allow them to take in information in various ways. These may include audio-books.
      • {% endif %} {% if auditory-processing-weakness-children3-5-recommendation == true %}
    • Consider providing the client with jobs or classroom chores to foster their sense of inclusion, responsibility, and engagement in the class despite their academic challenges.
      • {% endif %} {% if auditory-processing-weakness-children3-6-recommendation == true %}
    • The client would benefit from receiving instructional support within small groups and a low student-to-teacher ratio specifically around writing tasks.
      • {% endif %} {% if auditory-processing-weakness-children3-7-recommendation == true %}
    • It is suggested that the client be allowed to re-read and refer back to the text.
      • {% endif %} {% if auditory-processing-weakness-children3-8-recommendation == true %}
    • The client would benefit from academic instruction within an environment free from extraneous noises. This may entail ensuring other student’s making less noise, or other environmental modifications.
      • {% endif %} {% if auditory-processing-weakness-children3-9-recommendation == true %}
    • Instructors should aim to rephrase and repeat task instructions to the client when needed. Additionally, they should request for the client to repeat back task instructions either silently or out loud to ensure appropriate engagement despite sensory processing weaknesses.
      • {% endif %} {% if auditory-processing-weakness-children3-10-recommendation == true %}
    • Instructors should accommodate the client’s slower response time to auditory stimuli to allow them adequate time to process this information.
      • {% endif %} {% if auditory-processing-weakness-children3-11-recommendation == true %}
    • Providing the client with a routine and predictable structure within the academic setting will allow the client to better engage with the curriculum.
      • {% endif %} {% if auditory-processing-weakness-children3-12-recommendation == true %}
    • Instructors should proactively and frequently summarize and emphasize key information. To do so, utilizing a “chunking” strategy would be beneficial.
      • {% endif %} {% if auditory-processing-weakness-children3-13-recommendation == true %}
    • The client should have access to visual cues on tasks if and when appropriate.
      • {% endif %} {% if auditory-processing-weakness-children3-14-recommendation == true %}
    • When presented with homework tasks, the client should receive written instructions.
      • {% endif %} {% if auditory-processing-weakness-children3-15-recommendation == true %}
    • The client’s academic instructors should be receptive to the assertive requests put forward by the student so as to ensure an environment to best support their ability to adequately process auditory information.
      • {% endif %}
    • {% endif %} {% if auditory-processing-weakness-children2-recommendation == true %}
  • The client’s caregivers should play an active role in understanding the client’s auditory processing weaknesses and associated limitations given their current difficulties in writing. In turn, the client’s caregivers should maintain realistic expectations and ensure not to punish or reprimand the client for failure to complete associated tasks.
    • {% endif %}
{% if auditory-processing-weakness-for-children-&-adults-recommendations-freehand != undefined %}

Additional Learning Disability in Writing Diagnosis for Children recommendations: {{ auditory-processing-weakness-for-children-&-adults-recommendations-freehand }}

{% endif %}
{% endif %}
{% if WIAT-III == true or Nelson-Denny == true or WJ-IV-ACH == true or BRIEF == true or Conners-3 == true or D-KEFS == true or RBANS == true or NEPSY-II == true or QIK-CPT == true or Vineland-II == true or ADOS-2 == true or CARS-2 == true or GARS-3 == true or WISC-V == true or CTONI-2 == true or DAS-II == true or WASI-II == true or WAIS-IV == true or WJ-IV-COG == true or WPPSI-IV == true or WRAML2 == true or GORT-5 == true or WMS-IV == true or WRAVMA == true or Beery VMI == true or BASC-3 == true or PIY == true or H-T-P == true or MCMI–IV == true or MMPI-2 == true or MMPI-A == true or Rorschach == true or TSCC == true %}

Appendix

{% endif %} {% if WIAT-III == true %}

Conners-3 

{% if 24-content-scales == true or 25-dsm-symptom-scales == true or 26-indices == true or 27-screener-items == true or 28-critical-items == true or 29-validity-scales == true or 30-content-scales == true or 31-dsm-symptom-scales == true or 32-indices == true or 33-screener-items == true or 34-critical-items == true or 35-validity-scales == true or 36-content-scales == true or 37-dsm-symptom-scales == true or 38-indices == true or 39-screener-items == true or 40-critical-items == true or 41-validity-scales == true %}

Woodcock-Johnson IV – Tests of Cognitive Abilities 

 WJ-IV COG
{% if 134-comprehension-knowledge-gc == true or 135-fluid-reasoning-(gf) == true or 136-short-term-working-memory-(gwm) == true or 137-cognitive-processing-speed-(gs) == true or 138-auditory-processing-speed-(ga) == true or 139-long-term-retrieval-(glr) == true or 140-visual-processing-(gv) == true %}

WJ-IV COG Composite Score Summary

Index
Composite Score
% Rank
Classification
{% if 134-comprehension-knowledge-gc == true %}

Wechsler Memory Scale 4th Ed. 

 WMS-IV

Personality Inventory for Youth 

 PIY
{% if 110-cognitive-impairment-scale == true or 111-impulsivity-and-distractibility-scale == true or 112-delinquency-scale == true or 113-family-dysfunction-scale == true or 114-reality-distortion-scale == true or 115-somatic-concern-scale == true or 116-psychological-discomfort-scale == true or 117-social-withdrawal-scale == true or 118-social-skill-deficit-scale == true %}

PIY Composite Score Summary

Scale
T-Score
% Rank
Range
{% if 110-cognitive-impairment-scale == true %}
Cognitive Impairment Scale
{{ 110-appendix-piy-cognitive-impairment-scale-composite-score }}
{{ 110-appendix-piy-cognitive-impairment-scale-rank}}
{{ 110-appendix-piy-cognitive-impairment-scale-range}}
{% endif %} {% if 111-impulsivity-and-distractibility-scale == true %}
Impulsivity and Distractibility Scale
{{ 111-appendix-piy-impulsivity-and-distractibility-scale-composite-score }}
{{ 111-appendix-piy-impulsivity-and-distractibility-scale-rank}}
{{ 111-appendix-piy-impulsivity-and-distractibility-scale-range}}
{% endif %} {% if 112-delinquency-scale == true %}
Delinquency Scale
{{ 112-appendix-piy-delinquency-scale-composite-score }}
{{ 112-appendix-piy-delinquency-scale-rank}}
{{ 112-appendix-piy-delinquency-scale-range}}
{% endif %} {% if 113-family-dysfunction-scale == true %}
Family Dysfunction Scale
